Definitely recommend to everyone but especially couples!I absolutely adore staying at the Briar Patch Inn.   I've been here several times and have stayed in different cabins... I can't say I like one more than another, it's just the type of space you're looking for.    The cabins are tucked in to a wonderfully landscaped setting with Oak Creek bordering on one side.  There is a fantastic little seating area along the creek for meals, and then a little hidden spot which is perfect for drinking apple cider and enjoying the peacefulness of the river and surroundings.  I love the little paths through the property and little seating areas and gardens, not to mention watching the sheep.  The clubhouse is wonderfully rustic, along with all the cabins, and they serve a nice little breakfast.  If you're looking for pancakes, bacon, potatoes, etc... get a cabin with a kitchenette and cook it yourself because you will have fresh fruit, yogurts, granola (amazing!!!), etc. Bring games, books, or portable DVD players for entertainment at night, because the cabins don't have televisions.    Cell service is spotted throughout the property.  You may or may not have it. The only complaint I have is the fact that there are no comfy cushiony sofas or chairs to sink into.  The furniture they have is lodgepole with thin cusions-- and I personally think they're uncomfortable.  I'd love to have a small leather loveseat to read in rather than sitting up straight on a futon.I've visited the Briar Patch Inn and cannot wait to return! On both visits I stayed in the Creekside cabin and it is absolutely amazing! I found the cabin to be well-decorated in a cute rustic style, very clean, comfortable, and romantic. The sound of the creek flowing below is harmonious, and the outdoor fireplace is perfect for s'mores. Breakfast (both times) was absolutely AMAZING with a quiche to die for. My mouth is watering just thinking about it! You can choose to eat in the main lodge, take your meal to an outside lawn overlooking the creek, or take it back to your cabin. The small number of cabins makes the B&B very intimate and cozy, and the staff really tries to get to know you and meet your every need. You are secluded from the road, have a nearby swimming hole, and sheep graze in a small field. Happiness just oozes out of this place! Overall, the Briar Patch Inn is a wonderful place to stay with either a special someone or with a family group. The prices can be a little high, but it is well worth it! You can also keep an eye on their website or Groupon for specials. On a personal note - the Briar Patch Inn will always hold a special place in my heart as the place of my engagement! :)My family went to the Briar Patch Inn last week and we enjoyed it so much. Every where you turn there is a photo op- it is so beautiful. The breakfast by the creek is amazing and so relaxing. We stayed in the Eagle and it was spacious and comfortable. Definitely recommend.Adorable. The cabins are awesome-- we saw a few on our stay, and they were great. Comfy, spacious, and super clean. The whole place is so cool: trees and flowers, birds, squirrels everywhere, decks overlooking the creek, grills, even a couple of sheep. And let's talk about the breakfast: quiche, hard/soft boiled eggs, oatmeal, cereal, fresh bread/muffins, fruit, yogurt, and more, every morning. Plus cookies, coffee, tea, and cider all day. The service is unbeatable: I've never met such nice people. I would definitely stay here again.My friend recommended me to stay here.I planned my 2 nights getaway in November.Delightful place, but very pricy.They have good cracker & cheese snacks with apple cider.Very helpful front desk staff.Secluded and next to a creek so its really nice to kick back and relax.The property is beautiful, close to nature, has wooden rockaby bench swings, a hammock, some sheep, ... lovely.Bring some chopped apples so you can feed the sheep.Keep your hands flat when you're feeding them.I liked star gazing on the hammock at night.They give you a blanket for outdoor use which is nice.Our cabin had a fire stove/ furnace thingy.took a few tries but it was a lot of fun.Gets warm really fast, but once the fire goes out it gets cold really fast too.I like going and listening to the creek.I would go back again.I can't say enough good things about this place.  It's an Arizona gem.  The rooms are "comfortable rustic" (not fancy but perfect for a cabin in the woods type getaway).  The brunch is simple but delicious and the table seating overlooking the creek is beautiful.  On my stays there (about a year ago) brunch was accompanied by truly great live acoustic music that was perfect for the setting.  Had the privilege to meet the owner who lives next door and understood why this place has the peaceful energy it has, which i think is an extension of her personality.  I am regretfully taking away one star - which is hard to do - only because it is not pet friendly.  But, if you don't mind leaving Fido at home, I really can't think of a better place to unwind for a weekend.  Thanks Briar Patch.Charming setting along Oak Creek. Didn't stay here but enjoyed a delightful brunch on a warm summer day with a friend on the way to the Grand Canyon.First off, the breakfast was awesome.  Buffett style, you can pick what you want and however much you want.  Indoor and outdoor seating, you can sit and hear the creek.  The owners/workers are extremely friendly.  The grounds are beautiful and shady.  There are mulitple cabins to choose from for 2 - 10 people.My only two problems: The beds are low quality and uncomfortable.  Also, the website states they have "swimming holes" in the creek, but that is not the case.  It is wayyy too rocky and shallow to even dip in.Very charming little cabins scattered around 15 or so acres along Oak Creek. The water burbles in the background, the cliffs soar red and majestic above you, and the breakfast spread is really top notch.  The price is almost as high as the surrounding red rocks, but I guess if you want a really nice Sedona experience, it's not cheap.  As others have mentioned bring some sliced apples for the chubby sheep. Dip your toes in the creek (I really don't think you could swim in it) and take in some yoga on the lawn.  Just be sure to snap out of your serenity while pulling out of the Briar Patch Inn onto 89A, since the great unwashed are driving like maniacs on their way to Sliderock. Look both ways and be careful.This place was amazing!  A small collection of cabins nestled in the trees right along the Oak Creek.  The cabin was immaculately cleaned and beautifully furnished.  Every morning a delicious breakfast is served with quiche, fruit, fresh baked breads and more... and in the afternoons a snack of hot cider and cookies.The management and staff were so friendly and polite, they really made us feel welcome.  The ONLY complaint I had were the beds.  They were rock hard and I had an uncomfortable nights sleep.  With that warning taken into account, I would recommend this place to anyone!Stayed in the Tree Top room for two nights over a fall weekend. I was along for the ride with my friend who was on the first leg of a journey to start her life over. Briar Patch Inn is a good stop for that sort of a trip :)If you are looking for rustic, quiet and TM lifestyle, here's your place.  We were not. Although the staff was friendly at check-in, it is WAY over priced.really, $300 a night?  I was expecting so, so much more for the money. Mother Nature was very evident at Briar Patch but then again, I wasn't paying her. Improvements could include but definitely not limited to:  maybe two small bottles of water or even a small bottle of wine upon arrival?  What about a deck of playing cards in a drawer, or a board game?  Even checkers?  I shouldn't have to leave my room for these items either. A few trips to a local thrift store in town and you could have something for every cabin. And how about a few books to read?  Nothing heavy, maybe a romance, mystery or nice animal story?  What about a decent chair or sofa to sit?  The peeler log "sofas" were very uncomfortable, no back support until you hit the poles.  And then there's the soap. Just because something is au naturale and cost three dollars for a sliver of something resembling soap doesn't make it soap.  Didn't like that at all.  I realize this is vegan territory, hard for us carnivores, but breakfast was way too lightweight for our tastes.  I will say the coffee was good and nice large mugs.  The music? Well they "tuned up" for almost an hour before playing and by then our breakfast was done. Are they a relative of the owner or something?  Geez, all the CDs in the cabin, all eight of them, we're their recordings!!  A little nepotism?  Would have liked some Sinatra or even Placido to break up the Indian chant tunes.  We won't be coming back and I wouldn't recommend it either unless you wait until the very last minute to find a reservation like I did, and then this is what you get.  Mother Nature outdid herself in Sedona but I'll take Prescott, thank you very much.Hubby and I stayed at the Briar Patch for a little 1st anniversary get away.  What a great place!  It was our first trip to Sedona, and I wouldn't think about staying any where else on our next trip.  We had a lovely little cabin by the creek.  It was quaint and clean.  No TVs, no telephones, no sounds but the creek and the two resident sheep baa'ing occasionally.  Breakfast is homemade and healthy, perfect fuel for a day of sightseeing.  The staff is very friendly and helpful.It's nothing glamourous.  There's no room service, but if you're looking for a comfy, rustic getaway this is your place!  I do kind of wish there was a bath tub so I could soak a bit, but the wood burning fireplace makes up for that.Oh, make sure to get a massage by the creek.  Ahhhhh!We thoroughly enjoyed our stay here.  The babbling of Oak Creek while eating breakfast or enjoying a massage was magical.  We stayed for five nights with our three children who were charmed by the resident sheep.  The cabins are not luxurious but they have everything you need and are clean and comfortable.  The grounds are completely enchanting!  I look forward to returning again.

review_content: My sister and I recently stayed here while in Sedona. We were very comfortable. Rooms were clean. Free breakfast was good and the breakfast lady, whose name I can't remember, was awesome- really nice, going out of her way to make sure everyone was happy, including the kids. It is located centrally so it's easy to drive anywhere in Sedona you want to. It is an older hotel and I think it's a little pricey taking that into consideration.Ok for what we paid for it. Reasonably clean and comfortable. My only real complaint is the understaffed front desk. I needed to call the hotel prior to our arrival. The first two times I tried, no one answered the phone. When we arrived, the lone front desk girl (I say "girl" because she couldn't have been older than 18) was on the phone talking to DirectTV. (Some channels kept breaking up during our stay.) She ignored us and kept talking. We stood there from anywhere between 5 to 10 minutes until she finally completed her call and checked us in. The paying guest definitely did not come first here.Ordinary stay for a Hampton Inn, with the exception of a front desk staff that seemed pretty incompetent. I had to make several visits to the front desk due to confusion about the length of my stay (booked online for two nights but they said it was only for one and I'd have to extend my stay, if a room was available). Half the time there was no one at the front desk and then two different people didn't know how to extend my stay on the computer, so I had to come back and speak to a third person. They also charged my brother for one night as a no-show, although everything was paid in full on my credit card. It was quite a hassle. Breakfast was decent, although lacking in meat options (e.g. chopped meat in scrambled eggs) and fresh fruit. The lobby dining area also got quite crowded, so people had to share tables or eat in odd seating. Location was on a busy highway and not walking distance to attractions, although close to Whole Foods and Safeway. There was an empty liquor bottle in the closet when we arrived, so I guess housecleaning wasn't too thorough.Comfortable clean rooms but, as many brought up the breakfast is bad/mediocre compared to other Hampton inn hotels we've stayed at. The decor also feels outdated and rundown. I wish management would update service and accommodations as it would change my future stays here in Sedona.I enjoyed my stay at this Hampton Inn. Nice staff from checking in to those assisting with the complimentary breakfast to checking out. Complimentary breakfast included the usual fixings of oatmeal, muffins, scrambled eggs, potatoes, yogurt, fruit, and cereal. If you don't have time to sit and eat, there's a to-go bag of muffin, fruit, and water, but that's only offered Monday to Friday.My favorite part about staying at this particular location was the live music! There was a man who played music on his flute during breakfast and weekend nights. The melody matched the music nicely. He's a local Native American musician who plays at different venues and selling CDs for a living. His name escapes me at the moment, Bear something... This location itself is close enough to the "downtown" Sedona area, but not close enough to walk. However, there are a lot of great shops and restaurants near by. Behind this Hampton Inn is a nice residential area to star gaze on a clear night. It rained/snowed (mid-May, I know...very odd) one of the days, but ugly weather cleared out. The stars were beautiful. I would consider staying here again next time, but I'd probably work a little harder of finding a better deal. For the price paid, I later saw that it was on the high end for the area.This is one of those Hampton Inns that veers off from the expected Hampton Inn experience. The hallways are dismal; bordering on depressing. Dark, muted color scheme, unlike the bright/uplifting one that we stayed at in Phoenix. The Phoenix location felt upscale; this location does not.A sub-optimal aspect is that some Hampton Inns, like this one, do not provide shear drapes on the windows. So one has to decide whether to keep the drapes shut and use the room in darkness, or to open the drapes and be on display to anyone passing by. Decor/ambiance:  2 stars Service: 3 starsComfort: 3 starsBreakfast: 2 stars (sorry, but awful sausages and way over-cooked oatmeal)Would we stay here again? Probably, but if there was another Hampton in the area, we would try that instead.My family and I stayed here over the weekend of May 30-June 1 2015. The property is very nice and clean, both overall and our room in particular. It has a decent sized outdoor pool and hot-tub/jacuzzi which also were kept very clean. Free breakfast, which was just okay, but get there early or go later because seating is minimal. We also found this hotel to be a decent location - about 4-5 minutes from the heart if downtown Sedona by car, plus nearby shops, restaurants, and stores for wants and necessities.  We would have no qualms about staying here again.Gross motel. Either it's super dirty or there's mold around the toilet and shower in the bathroom.  Would not stay here again even if it were free (which is was for our stay due to points). Stick to other chains or the boutique resorts in the area, you can't really get worse than this place.I booked using Hilton Honor points, as I travel quite a bit for business.  This MOTEL was one of the worst Hampton's I have stayed at.  The hallways were dark, checkin was slow (there was no one behind the desk), the room was picked up but filthy - that was probably the worst.  The furniture was old and outdated, there was black mold in the shower and around the rim of the toilet.  We checked in, set our bags down, and wanted to get out ASAP.  The sheets kept popping off the corners of the bed.  In the morning, we did not partake in the free breakfast, we just wanted to get out of there.  On the main drag in Sedona, but no views.  There are a ton of local budget motels around if you are really trying to stay on the cheap (which this hotel was not cheap, it just felt low quality).  Otherwise, stay elsewhere.  You will sleep better.Hampton Inns are a "go-to" in my business travel, and are consistent.  Where a particular property flies under or over the bar is in the details.  As others have noted, this Hampton Inn isn't in the heart of the Sedona business or entertainment districts, but isn't inconvenient driving to either.  Actually, the reduction of traffic and noise makes this a positive.We found the front desk personnel to be engaging, personable and anxious to please.  Also on the plus-side, their lobby coffee (horrific in most Hampton Inns), was actually quite good.  Water pressure and temperature consistency, air conditioning, room size and furnishings, parking (behind the building) and WiFi bandwidth were each adequate.  I'm not a big breakfast eater, but my family and I found enough to get us started for the day.  Fresh fruit would have been a nice addition, and is a part of the typical Hampton Inn free breakfast.This does appear to be a late-century building, but is pleasant and-- hallway carpeting aside-- well-maintained.Ultimately, for whatever minor deficiencies we found, the area is so beautiful that we had no reason to diminish the Sedona experience through petty complaints.  We would stay here again.Cleanest Hampton Inn I've ever been too.. Nicest staff and just a great place to spend the night.. Nice free breakfast, coffee all day, spakling clean pool and jacuzzi.  Can tell the management cares , even housekeepers say hello and are always smiling.. I'm sold on this hotel !!! A+++Stayed on the President's day weekend.  Very busy (for winter at least).  The room was clean.  Beds were good.  Don't expect a view; but you also pay a lot less than the hotels with a view (which can reach up to twice the price).I have posted photos of the bathroom.The breakfast was good.  They had bacon and sausage patties, along with French toast and make yourself waffles.  They also had oatmeal. If they had scrambled eggs, then it would have been awesome - but only a few laces have cooked eggs.  But there did have hard boiled eggs.   And of course the various other breakfast items (pastries, fruits, cereals, juices, etc.).  They also had flavored little coffee creamers.  nothing expensive, but most places only give you plain creamer.I would recommend they cook their bacon and their sausage patties more.  not that it is was underdone, but it just wasn't browned.The pool and spa are typical size.  It was heated which is nice for winter.  The pool was not hot, but just warm enough to go in.The lobby was decent.  They had a computer to use.As some other poster said, when I got there (around 5:00, so not late) there was no one at the counter and I waited for about 5 minutes.  Of course 5 minutes seems like 15 minutes when you are standing there wondering why no one is there!Wi-fi, which is very important to me, was easy to get on and strong signal.  And it was free.  Parking was also plentiful and free.Generally a good experience.This hotel is very dirty. The first room we were checked into had a 3'x3' patch over the shower that was obviously not water sealed/protected since the paint was peeling and there was black mold. We pointed it out to the management and they reimbursed our stay as well as giving us a new room. That is the one aspect I am happy with. There was no argument, just an apology and a new room right away. The second room had mildew in the shower. We just scrubbed it off instead of creating another hassle for ourselves. We went to use the hotel pool that night. Since it had been thunder and lightning most of the day, we found it strange that the pool towels were all dirty and lying around with no fresh ones. It's not like anyone had been using the pool that day...After getting our bath towels and walking back down the hallway - which smelt like hot garbage-we decided not to use the pool or hot tub. If the showers and hallways were a dump, we didn't want to know how long it had been since the hot tub had been cleaned so we just skipped that. I would not suggest this Hampton Inn to anyone.Best thing about Hampton Inns is their consistency - rooms updated, good cleanliness, and good service.  I give it 5 stars for the value it provides.  Location is right in the middle of everything in Sedona.  Close to all kinds of restaurants and short drive to much of the sightseeing and hiking you would want to do.Clean room with a fridge, microwave and flat screen tv. Lobby is nice. Comp breakfast. Haven't used the pool or hot tub but they look clean and inviting! Sedona is so amazing, but can be pricey and this hotel is affordable! Around $150/night. Just minutes from the downtown "touristy" area.Pros:  Relatively inexpensive place to stay in Sedona. You generally know what you are going to get in a name brand hotel chain like this, with some exceptions noted below. Great location to attractions, sights and restaurants. Staff is courteous and attentive. Free breakfast and WiFi. Efficient check in and check out.Cons:  Hallway carpets need cleaning or need to be replaced. No hot meat items served with breakfast and not having them has not been my experience in other Hampton Inns I've been to. No in-room safe. Somewhat noisy heater in room.The hotel itself is a little worn-down, but it's very clean. My friend and I were looking for a budget hotel for our Sedona trip and it fit the bill. It's in West Sedona, but it was a short drive to the main areas of town. Easy check-in and check-out, courteous staff, free Wi-Fi, average budget hotel breakfast.My husband and I typically stay in Hampton Inn (we are Gold members, so we get perks).  The customer service seemed fine, and our room (king) was much larger than a typical hotel room.  We could have easily fit one or two roll-aways beds into the room comfortably. The hotel was a little on the "worn" side - this is not a "new" Hampton Inn, but it seemed clean.  It's a good location - close to the grocery store, restaurants, and centrally located to most of the major attractions.  My biggest complaint here was the breakfast!  The oatmeal, waffles, and cold item selection is adequate, but the attempt at hot food - Soggy, barely-done microwaved potatoes, "omelettes" with some sort of southwest "paste" (ham, cheese) in the middle.Overall, we would definitely stay here again for the price and location.This was by far the best place we stayed in during our Nevada/Arizona trip. It was clean, the staff was friendly and courteous, and the location was very convenient. Beds were comfortable, room clean, decent bathroom. Although it would have been nice if the vanity had not been in the bathroom. The breakfast was a little disappointing. There was a tray of fruit that appeared to be grapefruit with something else. It must have been frozen and then thawed. But it was yucky. I had to spit it out. The omelet looked good, but tasted bland except for the cheese. The oatmeal was cooked in a crock pot instead of being instant, and that was good. I would probably stay here again.As I sit here in my room at midnight after just checking in, I decided to quickly write down my experience this far with this location.  I also notice that one review has been written on the other account listed seperately for this exact hotel location.  And i share the sentiment even thought that review was written in 2009.VERY  UNWELCOMING STAFF. i approached the front lobby doors.  The automatic glass doors did not open?  There was a house phone next to the doors and so i picked up the phone and dialed "0".   A man answered the phone and said "what do you want?".  Really, this is exactly what he said.  I said i would like the door opened!  Heasked if I was a guest here and i told him i was.  Then he opened the door.  ......well i could continue on about this conversation but really, the point was I told him that asking me what do you want is not welcoming at all!  He just starred at me.  He asked for my credit card and swiped it.  The problem here is that I am a Hilton Honors member with gold status.  therefore, the hotel is never to ask me for anything when i walk in.  The key should be ready and there should be cold bottled water and cookies ready for me.  Neither was available and when i asked if he was the night manager he said "no-is there a problem?"  I had to be honest and just say yes-its YOU.  Neither of my room keys worked after I returned to the desk THREE times!  Seriously?  Is this even a Hilton company owned hotel?  This is the worst!  And the rooms have never been remodeled.  They are small and ovecrowded.  I didnt even have a computer chair in my room.  I instantly fell in love with Sedona on this first visit and would love to come back very soon.  But I have no desire to stay at this hotel ever!Also, I forgot to mention, during the day of my arrival, I called 4 times at different times before they answered the phone!  (I was trying to confirm my late check in)
review_content_20: Tried to get an early check in but the answer was no.  So them I asked can I just check in and leave my luggage. No too. I came back 1.5 hrs later and a different gentleman allowed me to check in at 1pm.I was not treated like an elite member. No newspaper to my room, no card saying my room wasn't serviced bc I had a "Do not disturb" sign up and offering for me to call them if needed. I'm disappointed!!! Spend the extra $50 overnight and go to the Hilton Resort. Too many kids for $149 per night.After my second night, I again didn't receive my newspaper though the rooms next to me did.  ???I will never stay here again. This is not the kind of service that Hilton builds their reputation on!On the other hand, the eating/breakfast staff was lovely and accommodating.Clean, close to restaurants/bars and good customer service, not to mention a nice pool.I can't give this hotel a good review. The floors were sticky. Also, the mattress was extremely hard and when I woke up at 3:00 am, my back hurt making it impossible for me to fall asleep again. I was looking forward to showering in the morning to help energize me, but the shower went from lukewarm to cool. I don't ask a lot from a temporary room, but being able to sleep and shower comfortably are what I'm paying for. Breakfast in the morning was much better than a typical continental.Nice, basic hotel. Everything seems clean and relatively well kept up. Rooms have standard amenities plus small microwave and fridge. Coffee, tea and hot chocolate were available all evening and even fresh cookies until they ran out. Nice common area was in use be a number of clients for playing board games. But the best of all was the manager on duty - Julia. She had great recommendations for places to eat and things to do, was remarkably professional and pleasant as she dealt with a constant stream of varied requests from guests.Service and cleanliness were great during my stay. However when I got back I realized they had charged my credit card numerous times without my consent for "incidentals". When I called to report the error, they did not offer any help & I had to contact my credit card company directly. Beware of fraud!Free wifi, friendly staff, clean rooms, good lobby with computer to print your boarding pass, and centrally located.  I would stay here again!  They also have free breakfast, which could be better, but is definitely adequate for something that's free (small boxed cereal, yogurt cups, waffle maker, and some frozen and reheated breakfast items, like potatoes and eggs).  The beds are comfortable and bedding is nice.  There was a mini-fridge in the room to store drinks and food (no mini-bar).Place is dirty, dingy, front desk Julia did not advise us of the free breakfast.I am on the phone trying to call them to get a receipt for my boss' stay.  The phone has been ringing 10 full minutes now and still no answer!I asked for assistance with an issue I had regarding some documents i needed scanned and emailed back home.  Without hesitation Jennifer took care of it, assisting me in sending the documents in a timely fashion. Fantastic customer service here!  Jennifer was wonderful!Best buy for your dollar. Clean facility, efficient and super nice staff. Convenient. Excellent suggestions for nearby eating. Very sufficient breakfast bar. Locally owned and operated. New Sedona residents, M. InglisThe building itself is not something you are used to! When you visit sedona youll see that the buildings are made to look like rock. So i thought it was a nice touch.  This one has a really nice lobby and friendly staff.  It also has a really good location.  Visiting the area I was given a map and found everything I was looking for from food to scenic areas for photos.  Also if you are interested in taking a pink jeep tour, they pick you up and drop you off from this hotel.All in all I can't say I can complain about this hotel.  It's nothing fancy (as most Hamptons aren't) but it's one of the better ones I've stayed at.Awesome stay!  My wife and I went on our first year anniversary and we loved it.  The jacuzzi was making a little too much noise and we called it in because we were trying to sleep.  They were very professional and upgraded our room.  We got a good night sleep.  The beds and pillows are very comfortable and clean.  The next morning we found out that they had a variety of breakfast items to choose from.  My wife and I made our own waffles and served ourselves warm potatoes bits that were freshly made.  They had fresh fruit, yogurt, cereal, juices, milk, coffee and more just waiting for us - it was all free!  In effect, we didn't have to have breakfast at a restaurant!  Later that day we asked the staff to help us plan our trip to the Grand Canyon and they were informative and exhibited alacrity.  My wife and I agree, we loved our stay at the Hampton Inn.  It was an aesthetically pleasing and enjoyable stay. Thank you!Unwelcoming staff, bare minimum rooms, tiny bathrooms with the appeal of a rest stop toilet. Forget it, unless your only alternative is to sleep on the side of the road.We ended up at this hotel by default after reader reviews told of major problems with similarly priced rooms (hard-sell time shares, peeling linoleum, stained carpets, noisy fridges, etc). The Hampton was delightful, with a well-designed building and grounds, convenient location, clean, spacious rooms, and friendly staff. A few reasons I give it 4 stars instead of 5: The Internet connection from the room (wireless) or the computer in the lobby is as s-l-o-w as maple syrup (better, of course, than hotels which have no Internet service or charge extra for it). The Internet server would not allow me onto Yelp (a prohibited site). I was trying to get reviews for restaurants, so I had to look up reviews on Expedia instead of Yelp. Why is this? The breakfast is not as good as advertised (frozen fruit: yuuuuk). But these are minor complaints compared to many places I have stayed that have far more defects, so  I would still recommend it.Nice hotel with good breakfast and friendly staffs but their wi-fi is not Mac friendly :(

review_content: Clean comfortable small stand alone units in a resort that shows pride of ownership. Each unit has a nice deck with table and chairs for dining outside. Each unit has a charcoal bar-be-que and there are larger shared gas units around the resort. Differs from other typical timeshares in that the units are stand alone and spaced attractively around small streams that end in rock fountains. Grounds are attractive and meticulously maintained.Entire staff is courteous and helpful in every way. WIFI is on again, off again in some units. AT&T doesn't service this area at all. Each unit has a wired telephone from which you can make unlimited free calls in the USAWe stayed at Sedona Pines for one night, and it was a pleasant experience. We had the two room cottage, and it was perfect for two couples, one with a baby. The main cottage had a sitting area, small kitchen, bathroom, and bedroom. The second bedroom, which was located across the deck, had a bed and bathroom. The deck provided a nice separation for privacy, while the main cottage was nice for the group to hang out. While the amenities weren't exactly modern (read, from the 80s), it had everything we needed to make our short stay comfortable. We took advantage of the mini golf course, which is pretty small, but has 18 holes and the equipment was easily accessible. Assigned parking spots were nice and convenient. We didn't try the restaurant or pool/spa, so I can't comment on those. I would give this place a solid 3.5 stars, but since half stars aren't available, I'll round up.Awesome place to stay!!! Been coming every year since it opened! Sparkling clean. Very well maintained. Free mini golf & nice pool & ADULT hot tub if you don't want kids around. Staff is very nice & helpful. 5 stars!!!!!Wonderful place! Very accommodating and friendly!Great weekend getaway! The big, not crowded, saltwater, lagoon style pool is a big plus. The rooms are more like a vacation home than a motel room, but you don't have to clean it or pay a cleaning fee - so you get the best of both worlds. The kitchenette is very nice, the bed and the sofa sleeper are very comfortable, the amenities are very high end and the property with the chair swings and ponds make you feel right at home. As far as wildlife goes, we had a big laugh when a bat dove for a June bug and buzzed my daughter in the pool, so who knows you might see something. There is a cattle guard, so javelin and deer will only be visible outside the perimeter.What a mess of a resort! Preface this with there was a random snow storm during our trip which had a huge impact on the quality of our stay.Cable went out in our room for 3 days and although the front desk informed us all of northern Arizona had lost their cable the rec room and gym conveniently still had signals. All of the activities were cancelled for our stay which is understandable as the freeway was treacherous the first night but was plowed by the next day. The restaurant was closed so we were snowed in with no food options,THEY CHARGE $45 for "CLEANING" where they swap your towels, throw out ONLY the bathroom trash, and take your sheets away without replacing them. THANKS SO MUCH.Nasty retired people living in the RV! Think they own the place! Harassed my dad and swung a weight at my mom's head. Called the front desk and they acted all concerned but never did anything about it or returned our calls.They made sure to sweep all the snow and ice off the steps of the cottages where people were checking in but were content with the rest of us slipping on our way down the stairs. No activities for kids which means they are running around and screaming in the streets.The front desk is a rinky-dink piece of trash compared to their sales entry and desk. sure makes you feel valued now that they already have your money.I overheard the front desk people saying how pissed off all their guests were and how many people were checking out. Turned into a ghost town the second night we were here even though they were booked through the week.You're also pretty far from Sedona compared to other resorts, like 10-15 minutes.I can deal with the claustrophobic small cottages and mildew sheets and towels but being stuck in here with no cable, or activities, NO WIFI SIGNAL (and red rock park tlaquepaque and downtown sedona all closed) was a living hell.They are single wide manufactured homes that have stucco over them. Nice decks added on and inside is in nice condition. The park is maintained nicely. We played miniature golf (free). There was no cell phone service we have TMobile but they have a wired phone you can use, just let them know yours didn't work so they don't charge you. There is no secured internet and it's made very clear at check in, would have needed to know this ahead of time since we had business needs to tend to. I guess they have sales pitches and breakfast that goes with it along with activities that you can pay to do? Bring extra whatever you need for less than 3 nights, you don't get maid service. They need to replace the couch and chair, the cushions are ruined for comfort. It's nice though to have a living room, small kitchen and separate bedroom.If you need coffee buy it at the store or buy it from them. Need a map, stop at the Tourist Center in town or buy it from them. You get my sentiment. There is however free laundry, how nice is that? I couldn't tell if the pool/spa was open so we didn't use it. Honestly, I was too afraid to ask the clerk who checked us in. I dealt with that at checkout with the manager. Mike seems to be doing a good job of turning things into a positie experience. If you have any issues call him in the morning, he dealt with an issue we had in a very professional manner. Hope I covered it all, I would have left a less positive review if it hadn't been for the Front Desk Manager (Owners pay attention to that comment and follow his plans for the front end of the resort).Pleasantly surprised. I booked this resort before I looked at the Yelp reviews and was quite aprehensive before we got here, but it appears that the management is quite responsive to issues brought up in Yelp Reviews. I came with elderly parents and grade school kids around Thanksgiving and stayed 5 nights. Kids can go into the pools and spas, there is just one spa that is adults only. They have tons of art classes for the kids and adults and they are wonderful. The kids made frog keychains and I did a watercolor class. Very fun! They have a playground, basketball court and miniature golf. All appropriate for kids. I went to a yoga class and the instructor was the real deal (like studio yoga); she was very good and able to include people of all different yoga experience/abilities. The units are pre-manufactured cottages and the layout is like a single wide trailer, long and skinny. My family (+ kids) stayed in one unit (one bedroom plus a pull out couch) and my parents had a separate bedroom attached via a deck (half of another unit). They had a separate bathroom. The units are new, ceilings vaulted and very clean. They have free laundry, and even give you detergent and dryer sheets! How cool is that? They have a microwave/convection oven combo, dishwasher, and enough dishes to feed my family Thanksgiving dinner. Parking is right outside the units. Since AT&T doesn't work here, they allow you to make calls to anywhere, from the landlines. They have computers in the office so you can check email. The wifi in our unit worked perfectly though. They have tons of movies to rent. The grounds are immaculately clean so any rodent issues previous reviewers had must be an anomoloy. We are in the desert and the resort backs up to wilderness areas and this is where these creatures live. The resort is 4 miles from Sedona (we measured it) off of a 4 lane highway. It only takes 5 minutes or so from Sedona. Beautiful.The cabins, which are small manufactured homes, are fine. They are very cozy, there is plenty of hot water, and the kitchens are equipped well enough to cook a basic meal. The couches and chairs and beds are comfortable, which is not always true of timeshare resorts.We did get a phone call, asking us to attend an informational meeting to sell us a unit. There was a gift available, as usual. We declined (From other experiences - don't go to one of these meetings if you enjoy relaxing on vacation - timeshare sales are notoriously aggressive. A dental cleaning is more pleasant, but I digress...)The WiFi is passive/aggressive. We were warned by the desk clerk that it "wasn't reliable" and he was oh so correct. You will get a signal for 2 or three minutes, then you'll get bumped off. Then you'll be on for 20 minutes, and every thing will freeze. And forget about making phone calls, getting texts or getting on the internet if you are an AT&T user. Zero to 1 bar. Our travel companion had much better luck with Sprint, which worked well (both phone and iPad).The cable (Direct TV) was also very spotty. It went out completely one day.It was winter, and very cold and we did not use the workout room or the other amenities, but we saw many others using the features. We were told about a yoga class and a craft sale.Overall, a nice place to stay. Don't depend on the wifi.Get out of your room and enjoy the amazing view of Sedona!First of all, this review is for the "Sales Presentation" - NOT THE RESORT itself. The resort itself has very friendly staff, cute cottages and welcoming. I like the fact that I can park my car in front of the unit and my room is right across from the huge adult jacuzzi (that closes at midnight). If I rank the resort -- it would be a five star. However, this review is for my experience with the sales staff at the sales office. When you check in for longer than a few days , they will ask the guest to see a concierge and the concierge will ask you to attend a timeshare presentation and they will give you a gift. This is what happened to me .... and I read the previous Yelp reviews and the same thing happened to another lady. Yeekee! Summary: I found the Sales Managers Darren to be extremely rude, horrible customer service, and I think he is a racist (because I can't think of any reason why he would act and talked the way he did). I don't want to make this a racist issue, but I can definitely feel there was discrimination from him. The other manager Lydia had no customer service skills either. The receptionists had attitudes and really initiated the entire terrible experience and it ruined our day in Sedona. Most Surprisingly, I spoke with the Broker - Greg (its a sales office, so this is considered a real estate office with licensed agents), and all he did was defend his employees - particularly Darren, saying that the manager has been with him for 15 years, etc.... I see where the entire staff get their customer service from. I wish they would hire a consulting company to come and train on customer service, also they should all go through a diversity course so they know how to deal with people from various cultures and backgrounds. This is what happened: I had a sales presentation appointment for a 2pm, I went there early at 11am trying to see if I could attend early so I could leave Sedona and go to another city. ( I told the Concierge Lady that I was going to do that). I showed up about 11:02am and the girl on the left of the counter helped me, I learned that the presentation doesn't start until 11:30am. I said okay, I would love it if they could squeeze me in if people don't show. I proceeded to sit on the couch and wait until 11:30 to see if all their appointment showed up. The receptionist had no clue and didn't understand what I was saying or try to do. She ask the girl next to her, a girl with dimples, she too had no clue and didn't understand the process. They think that I want to be seen "NOW," which is not the case, I want to wait to see if I could take someone's spot if they are a "no show". I sat on the couch for about 15 minutes or so, then I went to the girl on the left and said "is there any paperwork I need to fill out for either this presentation or the later presentation?" she said "no, you already filled out all the paper already (I brought my confirmation letter with me)" then she proceeded to say "we still can't take you right now ....." I was thinking in my head .... I know, I was just asking if I need to fill out any paper for this presentation or the 2pm presentation."???? Then she whispered to the dimple girl, then the dimple girl went to the back, then a manager came out at around 11:20am (Lydia is her name), and said we can't take you "right now". I explained to her --- I understand you can't take me "NOW"; if its okay with her that I would prefer the 11:30am session and I understand if everyone showed then I wouldn't be able to. However, I would like to wait until after 11:30am to see if there are any "no shows" so I could take their spot, she said "sure", it would be more like 11:45am. I said okay, I will wait if she doesn't mind, she said okay. Side note: From the moment she came out to the moment she left .... I sensed a little attitude.Meanwhile, I could hear the receptionist say that they are waiting for 6 more parties to show up. I counted 4 parties that came in. So I am thinking, we might have a chance .... 2 parties didn't show so 2 spots may be available. 11:45am came and gone. Everyone, including the 2 receptionist left to the back since 11:40am. So I waited 10 more minutes until 11:55am and proceed to go find the manager-Lydia, whether we could be seen or not. At this point ... I had already been there 1 hour. At this point, the receptionist came back, and I began to tell the receptionist that Lydia said that we would know at 11:45am ..... Lydia came at this point and said "we can't see you now," you have to come back at 2pm. While talking to Lydia .... Darren (whom I never spoke with prior, started SCREAMING and said we don't need to come back at 2pm. Talked demeaning ....I wish Greg, the Broker, in charge of these agents could see the surveillance video of how rude his employee Darren treated us and was extremely rude and insulting. (I notice they had surveillance on the outside - not sure if they have it insideSEDONA's finest tourist trap with quaint cabins. Enough to drain the charge from this sacred and energetically powerful land is a marketing scheme for time shares aimed at tourists. The exchange of energy and time with these people is not worth the gifts. Be weary.I got an online deal to stay at this place so I decided to give it a try during MLK weekend.It's a timeshare but they never tried to sell anything to me which I appreciate it because we weren't gonna buy. The only reason why we stayed there was because I got the deal. I imagine they offered the deal to make it people go but the tour or presentation was voluntary. They mentioned it at check in and we just didn't request it during our stay. I thought they'd ask about it when we checked out but they didn't even mention it.Checking in and checking out was easy. Management filled in my form for my restaurant.com gift card that was part of the deal without putting pressure on me to do their timeshare presentation.Calling it a resort is maybe too much but the place's actually very nice. Very close to Sedona and they have tons of amenities. They had daily classes and activities. Free Wi-Fi, free laundry and a place for kids to play. There's also an 18 hole minigolf!! Super fun! We didn't try their restaurant/bistro, though. They also offer room service :)The cottage itself's very small but it's fine for a short stay for a couple (even with a kid, it's fine). 4 adults may be too cramped in there, though.Our cottage had wood floors and the kitchen was super nice. Electric stove and all the appliances you need. They even have a dishwasher!! They provide with all the basic tools you need to cook (pots, pans, silverware, plates, glasses, wine glasses, bowls, you name it!) and even some coffee filters, sugar, creamer and dishwasher detergent. Kitchen had a coffee maker, blender, electric can opener, bottle opener, microwave oven... I mean, you could cook any meal in there! We didn't use the laundry facility but there was some detergent and softener in the cottage too.Bathroom was a good size for the size of the cottage itself. They provide with tons of towels (even extra towels in case you wanna use the pool). Masted bedroom's tight but you don't really need more space. Tons of storage all over the cottage. Nice TV, DVD player in the living room and bedroom area.Signs on the freeway are too small and we got lost. Also, the sofa bed in the living room was extremely uncomfortable (and noisy) but that's just a problem with any sofa bed, I believe. A daybed with a trundle bed below may be a better option but that's just my opinion.Distance from the city wasn't too far at all. Less than 10 min by car to get to Uptown Sedona. Surroundings were very quiet and relaxing. There are water fountains and water running all over the property.If I get another deal like this one, we're definitely coming back for another long weekend.All in all I can say the resort was terrible. However, the rooms were really small. It was okay for the both of us but any more than two people and it would get really cramped really fast. The place was amazingly clean though. The stuff was very helpful. The pool was a good size and warmed to the point where it was comfortable not too cold. The exercise room was a tad small but nobody used it so I don't think they will be upgrading soon. The reason for the three stars... No wifi, no cell phone service! My understanding that it's OK to get away but when you're in a strange place of relying on Google Maps this can be a real pain in the ass. Also how was I supposed to use my Yelp account! Sedona is a beautiful place but been there done that. This is Steve justice comfy at home signing off.This is off the path about 7 miles away from Uptown Sedona and you will have to drive if you stay here. I was hoping for a place that could be closer to the trails, etc.If you are looking for a resort to relax this might be your place. However I did not see any views from here. You will have to most likely drive to enjoy the views of Sedona. I would say keep looking if you want a 5 star resort experience.I recently vacationed in Sedona with my boyfriend. It was my first time there, and my first vacation in a long while, so I was ready to relax and enjoy time away from work.The resort is not actually in Sedona, it's about 10 minutes from Uptown Sedona. We stayed in one of the units that included two cottages; one with a bedroom/kitchen/bathroom/living room and the other with just a bedroom and bathroom. PositivesJacuzzi:Huge, clean, powerful jets and a waterfall.Towels:Lots of towels, too many for just the two of us.Parking:Directly in front of the cottage, assigned.Other:Basic kitchen utensils included.Vaulted ceilings.NegativesDoors Opening and Closing:We made 4 trips to the front office to get new entry cards in order to get the correct set that opened both of our units. Even then, we had intermittent issues with opening one or the other cottage doors throughout our stay. So we never really knew when we would have access to our belongings.Also, the entry doors don't close! Be warned that you may think your door is shut, but it isn't. We had to push against the doors with our full body weight in order to get them to latch properly.Fire Extinguishers:The fire extinguishers in both cottages were not up to code. The tags on the extinguishers did not reflect that they had been checked or serviced since their installation in November 2012.WiFi:WiFi is free, which is probably why it doesn't work with a damn. We were one of the closer units to the front office (where I assume the WiFi originates) and we weren't able to use our tablet for most of the time. Also, the resort has taken it upon them to block their guests from accessing adult websites. Yes, I'm serious.Linens:The blankets, linens, and towels smelled badly. I couldn't have the sheets or blanket next to my face because it made me feel nauseas. Also, the blankets are horribly thin, so I would suggest bringing along your own or requesting more of theirs, but remember that theirs smell pretty bad.Heater:On our first night there, the heater in the bigger cottage broke around 4am. It was 52 degrees in our cottage! The resort boasts that they have staff at the front office 24/7 "for guest convenience". However, that proved to be incorrect because we tried calling all of the extensions listed for the front office/manager's office from 5:30-7am with no answer. We ended up switching to the smaller cottage around 7am (the heater in there wouldn't turn off!) We finally reached someone at 7:30am who told us that she couldn't do anything because the guy that fixes stuff wasn't in yet, so we'd have to wait. We called back at 8am and she said he would be over shortly, which turned out to be another 45 minutes. We were in the middle of getting ready for our day when the guy showed up, said he fixed it, and left. We left shortly after him for the day. When we got back, the temperature was only up to 56 degrees which I attribute to the sun, not the heater. We decided to sleep in the smaller cottage for the rest of the trip. We're sure that the heater still hasn't been fixed.Noise:The groundskeepers start their leaf blowers and lawn mowers around 7am, so sleeping in is impossible.Kitchen:The kitchen is "galley style" which means it literally IS the hallway from the bedroom to the living room. It's functional, but ridiculously tight. Only one person can work in there at a time.Other:This is a time share resort, so they try to give you the sales pitch to buy a cottage or whatever. We politely declined, and that was pretty much it.The provided soaps smell awful. And there is a card next to them indicating they are a "one-time gift, not meant as a provision", which means the resort will not provide more throughout your stay.The phones in both cottages would randomly beep (loudly) throughout our stay. We aren't sure what that indicted, but it was annoying.Stray cats. Stray cats everywhere.I received a free cruise in the mail from Sedona Pine Resorts. I called the number and I was told I had to go listen to a presentation. I ask them if this was the place by Desert Ridge and he replied yes. He said since I had not been in the office for a couple of years they would like to see me again. I told him I was not able to buy because I was in a car accident where I broke my neck, had to sell my house and I am putting everything back together again so I want not in a place to buy anything and if I was going to buy it would be a house. They gentleman on the phone said it was fine and set up the appointment for 1/31/15 at 11:30I showed up for my appointment and an older white hair man named Bob walked me back to his cube. I was honest up front with Bob that I could not buy right now because of my situation. Bob started looking at me with slanted eyes and said if you are not going to buy what should we talk about. I told him he could give me the presentations. He started giving me a nasty attitude and replied verbatim "why would I waste your time or mine by doing that?" And he just stared at me with dirt eye. I grabbed my phone because I was very uncountable and I replied to a text. Bob says to me "if you do not but down your phone the 90 minutes starts now." I told him he was being rude making me feel unconfutable and I wanted to speak to him manager. He then continue to give me even a worse attitude as he went to grab the manager.After sitting in Bob's cube for about 15 minute... Jim the director shows up. I explain the situation to Jim. He said he remembered me from 2 years ago. I told Jim I could not buy and how Bob had treated me. I told Jim I explained to the guy on the phone I had been here before and I was not able to do anything. Jim proceeded to scrunch up him face and squint his eyes at me and tell me they cannot have people on their phones playing scrabble. I told him jim, Bob was being rude so I grabbed my phone to reply to a text. Jim then asked me who I spoke with on the phone. I told him I had no clue. Then Jim started to get more rude and scrunching his face at me. I told him I did not appreciate him treating me rude because I was not going to buy. He asked me what he was doing to be rude and telling me Bob was not rude to me either. I scrunched up my face mocking him and showed him what he was doing to me.He said I would have to sit with Bob for the remaining time. I expressed I did not feel comfortable with Bob. Jim got up look around for a minute and came back to tell me that I would need to reschedule because there was no one else to help me. I told Jim I was not going to rescheduling, that I drove 30 minutes and I had been in the office for over 40 minutes. I told him I would watch a video. He told me to leave the office. I asked for my cruise invitation back and he refused to give it to me and threated to call security. I have never been treated so rude and hurtful by a company in my life. This was the most unprofessional people working and representing a company. I was upfront about not be able to buy and was treated rude, had things turned around on me and wasted my Saturday morning. I get they are about sales but I was honest and I cannot believe you have these types of people representing your company. I will never stay at one of your resorts and I will let everyone I know not to go to one of these presentations.Pleasant but we won't be back. Not enough room for big kids and adults but quaint as it is a sweet RV park. Activities' breakfast was limited and prompt but free, informative and we won a cool prize. Not a great place for kids- this is definitely the post retirement set and most aren't happy to see kids. The don't allow kids in any spa and we were posted up across from the Lagoon which is a pool sized spa. Trust me the other guests will freak out if your kids go in the spa or make noise in the pool. It really is an old folks home. Don't waste your weeks/points if you are younger than 65.The update on RCI points isn't worth your time spent from 9-12 with small children despite the 90 minutes they insist and told them repeatedly what we were interested in. Heard nothin about the new resort and loads about our sales ladies' previous vacations. Diamond has a more concise presentation without the the 3 hour bottom line for essentially the same system. They didn't honor our interests at all and have turned us from the system. Kids just sat and watched TV- no activates or crafts. Diamond has real child care, tye die shirts, keychain a, a bag of stuff and real food. Can't say the same here- it was a timeshare person who regretfully admitted she had to go "babysit" while we were at reception. I nearly had a heart attack as a stay home mom- this girl didn't give a shit and at that moment I was nearly done. They literally watched movies/games and that girl didn't interact at all. Our kids were upset that it took longer than the 90 minutes promised and are still debating if the jeep tour was worth our time. Maia was pleasant to my husband but ultimately routinely insulting to me which ruined the deal- just from the moment I voiced hesitation. Don is a closer and adorable- he does well for his job and is appropriately suited but still a closer. Darren and Don were charming and pleasant . Darren was super charming and I'm sure does well- if you're his wife- he loves you and gushes about you!!! You are fortunate! ;)However we have had other women who were far more charming and pleasant- she was assumptions . Insisting I breed negativity? WTF? Us so cal people dont believe you're vortex theories BTW we don't use our money to buy $5 lattes everyday or $6000k purses but should I assume it's a compliment that you think we do? Restaurant on property is fantastic and staff is working their buns off-Make a legit happy hour and this place will take off- took the night off from Elote and it was really great. Get some legit specials and live music and this could be great!!!Super cute, clean cottage. Kitchen well outfitted...small but mighty. Stove top, microwave, coffeemaker, full fridge with icemaker.Comfortable bed. Sleeper sofa is very acceptable. Super awesome shower. Big and strong water pressure. Flat screen TV, cute dining area. So much packed into 399 square feet. We skipped the "free" breakfast and timeshare presentation. We did eat at the cafe twice. Both very good meals. Well priced, great service. Spa hot tub is so large it is better described as a small pool. Very nice and clean. Difficult Wifi connectivity, but they warned us that may happen. Would recommend! Enjoyed being away from the crowds.I rated this pace 5 stars for the following reasons.- we were comfortable- we did not have to eat out- kitchen was useful- The unit was very clean- plenty of hot water- parked right out front- Free laundry soap providedWe were a family of 4 + dog in a 1 bedroom; 1 bath; pet friendly unit. We stayed for 2 nights. There is a front porch with benches table and 2 chairs. All we used the resort for was to sleep and eat while we Mtn biked and hiked in Sedona; we did not use any of the resorts amenities.It is conveniently located for the area. 5 miles to Safeway grocery. 20 miles approximately to Jerome, AZ. We found the unit comfortable the kitchen was well equipped minus an oven. Our unit had a grill (park style) our front which we used to cook hamburgers. The one bedroom had a queen size bed that was not uncomfortable but not the best nor the worst mattress. The bedroom is small, me and the wife could not pass each other. There is a small TV with cable in the bedroom. The kitchen is a galley style not much counter top space. We cooked breakfast and dinner.The fold out bed had a very thin mattress glad I didn't sleep on it. There was a dinner table with a bench and two chairs. We eat all our meals at the table. Things I didn't like- Wi fi was spotty- Our units bedroom faced 89A at night we could here the road noise.Things to note:- this place is a time share- they only clean the rooms once a week- There is a kid free spaWe have been at this resort three times. The accommodations were wonderful for us. However, the bedroom across the patio offered basic bedroom amenities which could have been enhanced w/ a small refigerator and microwave. Some of the negatives are that the resort is not in walking distance to any stores, gas stations, or, in our case, towers for receiving calls on our cell phone. One recommendation is to offer a shuttle to town (5 or 6 miles away) so that one is not "stuck" if there is no car available.
review_content_20: OK: Admittedly, the units are very small and the Internet is iffy. Otherwise, this is so worth it.Staff was fantastic. Helpful, informative, gracious, and nice. We got kind of lost late at night getting there and the security guard met us at the entrance to guide us into the place.The unit was spotless and very well equipped. I'm a foodie and love to cook, evenon vacation. I turned out some wonderful meals in the kitchen. I was surprised not to have an oven, but discovered a way to make crispy-crust delicious pizza using a frying pan with lid. My husband raved about it. Also made big. light sourdough English muffins w/o the oven.The place was perfect for 2 of us, each with our own computers and lots of books. Great shower and jacuzzi soaking tub in the unit.While people complained about the setting, they neglected to mention the grounds, that are absolutely lovely: Fountains, beautiful landscaping with native plants and rocks, little streams, and a number of small roads you can walk around for some exercise and to get a great view of mountains from the back or the property.We got internet in the unit just OK, but it was great at the office and we didn't mind going there to check emails.The location was perfect bc it was quiet. We did day trips everyday so we were out in the car anyway. We hiked several times with a very short distance from the place, so we found the location convenient.The pool area was very attractive and comfortable. On Saturday night, they featured a 1/2 hour concert by an Indian flutist that was really impressive...and I was a music professor, so it's a big deal when someone can impress me!All in all, a very good time. We'd definitely go back.This is a really tough one as I'd prefer to give it 3 1/2 stars.  With a 4 star ranking, I'd definitely look forward to going back.  With three - it's OK but not my first choice.Positives!  Super friendly staff, immaculate grounds (many people keeping it clean, amazing), very clean rooms, vaulted ceilings, light/airy, heated pool, miniature golf and very nice community.  Wow, so many positives....why only 3 stars?Negatives.  The same everyone states.  Zero view, far from town, internet is a joke (internet is ALWAYS a huge factor in reviews!!!!  Fix the internet and I'd add a star), layout of the modular homes (cramped for a family of 4), fitness center is MEH at best, and activities were also MEH.  Also, the laundry is separate - a HUGE negative with a family.  We are Wyndham owners and perhaps I've  gotten accustomed to a higher standard.  Wyndham's hit our demographic perfectly - it's all about family (6 and 9 year old) and over-delivery.  Wyndham will actually call during the stay to make sure we're happy.  While there were families at the resort, it was a broad mix.  That broad mix kind of gave the resort the feel "We're trying to be everything to everyone, yet miss the mark with everyone".  For instance, the pool is heated and nice, yet boring - it's just a pool.  The activities were from BINGO to childrens crafts - nothing exciting.  You see grandparents walking, kids walking and couples walking.  While this sounds perfect (and usually is), it was a slight miss and the lacked the 'buzz' you get at 4 and 5 star resorts.As for the awful reviews - I fully disagree.  This is a solid resort and does not deserve the 1 and 2 star rankings.  Just because the internet sucks, there are no views and it's not close to town does not make it ghetto!  Realize what you're getting and you'll be fine.There were two bad service experiences.  First was the free breakfast - get there EARLY!  We were a few minutes late (we're on vacation!) and they had no available seats.  Try being the Dad (feeling like an idiot!) and telling the family we need to leave and not have breakfast.  Worse, a vendor told me in front of my family to arrive on time next time.  Yeah - that hurt.  The other bad experience was William who tried to sell us a timeshare.  He was misleading and withheld critical information.  I've done a LOT of research on timeshares and know what to look for - he intentionally 'fluffed' far too much.  He also said he would pay us to sell our Wyndham Timeshare and give us an RCI timeshare at no cost - hmmm. In the end - he wanted us to pay $18K!  Worse, we explained we NEVER buy retail - often picking up a timeshare for free (check out TUG) in the aftermarket.  Why waste our time knowing the answer is NO.  He left such a sour taste in my mouth I still cannot stop thinking how awful he was.  The saying "You know a salesman is lying when their mouth is moving." defines William.So, when you put it all together - this is a 3 star resort.  Go early for breakfast, DON'T listen to the sales pitch, enjoy being off the grid, be happy to be away from the crowds and this is closer to a 4 star resort.  For us, this is good enough, but a Wyndham is what we enjoy.Really nice and pretty resort with nice private cottages and lots of amenities. BUT, the place is far from civilization, and if you expect to use the internet here while you are in your unit you can pretty much forget about it. The wifi is weak and unreliable, you have to go to some common area like the office or the laundry. Normally I would still be ok because I have a generous cellular data plan, but AT&T doesn't work worth a flip right here. That is not the resort's fault, but that means I can't really use my mobile phone or internet while I am here, so I will not be back unless they fix this.We stayed for 4 nights. We booked through RCI. Truthfully, the only reason I picked this place to stay was because we had expiring points and needed to use them and this was the only place available at the time. I didn't have high expectations but was mildly surprised at how nice and comfortable it turned out to be. Yes, there's an '80's feel to the cottages but everything was well-maintained and CLEAN. Our unit - they call them cottages - was close to the laundry which was great because I really needed to do some. Check-in was quick and easy, checking out was fine except for the $45 resort fee that we were charged (which probably pays for the "free" internet wifi, "free" laundromat, "free" gym, etc). I think that since the resort fee is a mandatory charge, then just charge it at the beginning of my stay instead of zapping me with it when I'm about to leave. It really was the only irritating thing about our stay.The resort is a few miles outside of the tourist area of downtown Sedona so a car is necessary. If you want to be IN Sedona, don't stay here. It's quiet and the units (or cottages) are spaced far enough apart that you don't hear your neighbors at all. I liked that we don't share a wall with anybody unlike a hotel where you can hear your neighbors flushing the toilet, taking a shower or talking. My husband I took daily walks at dusk and except for the maintenance golf carts, we sometimes felt like we were all alone.The one-bedroom cottage is small. We're not big people and it was still tight in both the bedroom and bathroom. It's supposed to fit 4 people but don't believe it. The one-bedroom unit is designed for two medium-size adults to move around comfortably without bumping into each other. The shower/tub was pretty spacious, though and the water pressure was nice. There was plenty of storage in the bedroom and bathroom for all our stuff.There were more than enough towels and linens for two people. And they even provided small bottles of shampoo, conditioner and lotion which isn't common in most timeshares I've been to. The kitchen is galley-style and has room for only one person to work in there. But we ate only breakfast in the cottage and spent our days out. When we arrived, the table was set and the radio was on and playing some very relaxing music. The kitchen was stocked with everything we needed including pots, utensils and plates (Corelle). No oven in the kitchen but the microwave is also a convection oven. However, I didn't go to Sedona to cook and bake so that didn't matter to me. The unit has lots of windows so it feels very open and spacious. I liked all the light coming in but my husband didn't like it so much early in the morning when he was trying to sleep in! Also our bedroom was adjacent to another cottage's air condition unit which was pretty loud during the day. However, with temps in the 50s at night, the A/C units didn't come on at night (thankfully!)We used the laundromat, the adult spa, and played mini-golf but we didn't do any of the scheduled activities.The location of the resort, despite being outside of Sedona has absolutely no views of any of the beautiful red rocks. Wifi was spotty but adequate. We weren't in Sedona to sit in front of our laptop and update our Facebook status either so spotty wifi wasn't a big deal. I found that most of the recent photos I found on the internet of Sedona Pines were accurate. The resort itself is very clean and looks to be regularly maintained. Frankly it was way better than I thought it would be despite reading some unhappy reviews about it being in a "mobile home with stucco". The units are so much better than that. I'm really glad I stayed here and would consider it again next time we're in Sedona.this place deserves 5 stars even though it's not a five star resort. But they have 5 star service and a great vibe.there's no granite in the kitchen; it's small. But everything you need is in the kitchen and it's in great working order. I burnt a pan and they brought me a new non'stick pan that was bigger and brand new (haha that's cool)there really isn't a "sedona" red rock view, but the hot air balloons are there in the mornings. Their pool(s) are awesome (salt) and in great shape. The laundry room was massive and free! Bam!This place has individual units; no shared walls; no BS. You have a private deck with table and chairs and your own charcoal BBQ. Really unique for a timeshare. They even cleaned out my old briquette from the nights before when I grilled! Ya dawg!You are on vacation. Unpack your shizzle and go hiking. You'll be comfy back at the Sedona pines when you get back.The rooms are a touch small, but incredibly quiet. It is far above some of the hotel chains that were closer to the heart of town. The fact that you are provided your own BBQ outside the patio instead of having to use communal grills next to the pool is a plus. I never had issues using the WiFi as I am posting the review with it now. The points value even during peak season is incredibly reasonable. I will state this, it is more of a couple's retreat than a family get away based on the size. It would feel like packing a family of 5 into a motor home if you have little ones. It is close, but when it is a weekend get away for a couple that has been overworked and had little time with each other for most of the year it was ideal. I preferred that we were out of town for the stay, we were greeted with that impressive red rock wall every time we drove into town to visit the sites. It took my breath every time.So beautiful quiet and tranquil, had a great week there this week! Thanks!  Can't wait to go backStayed here a week with our RCI weeks.  The grounds are kept very nice and the free laundry facilities are a plus.  Kitchens are tiny but do have all the utensils / pots / pans you could want although they do NOT have a proper oven (the microwave can work as a small convection oven). Annoyances are the size of the units (small is fine but these things are tight - no real wiggle room if you have a few people in there), only a queen bed,  and their wifi pretty much never works unless you are sitting in the reception area.  One other regret is this is NOT in the town of Sedona - it's just South (only 5 mins - granted - but better to be in town I think).(Note we stayed there October 2010 - Yelp says it's closed - it's not)this place reminds me of Motel 6, I should have found one of those. I will not stay there again. Service staff just OK. Rooms small, WiFi was spoty, kitchen really small.As a time share owner at an RCI resort, I am sorely disappointed in the way this place conducts business.  Horrible service to people who become a part.  Beware!The only draw back is it is a bit outdated (a bit of an early 80's feel) ....other than that the place is adorable and the staff is really nice. A great place to stay if you plan on spending time in surrounding areas and not just sedona.This was a great vacation for us.  The suites were comfortable and the service was very good without being overbearing.  It was exactly what we needed after a cold winter in Canada.This is a really cool timeshare property - all units are self-contained cottages. There are flowing water streams and fountains all over the property, very relaxing, very zen. There is a great restaurant on property run by a Paris-trained chef yet reasonably priced. The staff are wonderful and free entertainment is provided every evening. We liked being outside of town yet within a few minutes drive. There is a red rock formation behind the property and the area is very scenic. We will definitely visit Sedona and stay here again!

hotel_name: Arroyo Pinion Hotel, an Ascend Hotel Collection Member
review_content: If you are coming to Sedona for a trip, not familiar with where to stay, and want to keep things straightforward, here you go:1) Uptown/west Sedona = doesn't matter. You can drive where ever you need to go and it's easy. 2) Paying extra for a view seems silly when you are out hiking and likely just going to sleep. 3) If you stay in Uptown, you will have a LOT OF TOURISTS. My rate was totally fair considering I had a jacuzzi (omg, right) and a king bed.The rooms are clean and try hard to give an upscale vibe. Parking was easy, and the room had a small patio (that didn't have a view, but a nice place to have an end of the day glass of wine) and the breakfast options are vast (waffles, hard-boiled eggs, oatmeal, sausage, etc). I would absolutely stay here again.Yes, the other reviews are correct in that the place is a little noisy. They have a little basket in the room with bottled water and a treat, as well as ear plugs.We had a great time staying at this hotel. Upon arrival and learning that we were celebrating our first anniversary, the hotel allowed us to upgrade our room to a king suite with a jacuzzi tub (we reserved the room through Priceline which resulted in a 2 queen bed) The room was very clean and came w complementary water, pretzels and popcorn. The bed was very comfortable and the shower was huge!After around 30 minutes the staff at the front desk called and mentioned they had something for us at the front desk. They gave us a box of chocolates and a lovely card for our anniversary. The staff obviously care about ensuring their customers have a great experience. There was free breakfast in the morning which was fairly good. Our only complaint was that the hot tub was closed for the season. We highly recommend staying here at the Arroyo Pinion hotel.The hotel is ok, not the best in the area.  The rooms n building itself is a bit out dated, but with the price is comparable.  Walls are thin, people like to close their doors hard, so you will hear a loud slam everytime someone just let go their doors.  Pet friendly is a plus, but it comes with a price for 20 bucks per day per pet.The afternoon staff, I think his name is Robert? He was wonderful and professional.  He called after we checked in to make sure everything was ok. However the morning staffs were not as great...need to improve their communication skills a bit.  I understand that they were busy the night before and no early check in, but the first reaction I got was not to pleasant from the staffs.  We offered our information to input in their system, so we can speed up the process once the room is ready. Then we were just going to get some breakfast they offered in their lobby since we have to wait around, the staff member got loud and told us that we couldn't do that since we were not "offically" checked in...however I did paid for the room through priceline and they took my credit card info.  Just because I was not "offically assign" to a room number, so we were not consider a valuable customer?!  To be honest, she made us feel cheap like we were so greedy that we tried to score "free food"!!!  After she made a loud embarrassment of the situation, then she said it was ok just for this time, so we could have the food...really lady?!! They need to learn to speak to customers in a professional way, not tring to get their point across by "talking down" to their customer specially in front of others guests in the hotel...we are adult here, no one is tried to be low class or acting stupid.  We understand that there are rules, but it could be handled in a better way, perhaps speak to your guests in a softer tone or in private.  No one wants to be speak to like we are some low lives who were so hungry need to steal your food!!I was really impressed with the staff, one staff member in particular by the name of Sedonah was exceptional in terms of customer  service. She went above and beyond to make sure I was happy. If you decide to stay here, ask for Sedonah. She will take good care of you.More like 2.5 star rating.Pros: friendly service and big roomsCons: noise. It was so loud all night that couldn't even sleep (despite using the ear plugs they left in the room). If you are looking for a good night sleep or relaxation, this is not the place.
