Other than that, it was nice.What outstanding service and accommodations.  The hotel is clean and rooms are adequate.   I love the two Door entrance and private balconies.  Nobody running in front of your main window.  Not bad for 114 a night!!Great hotel - super friendly and helpful staff, spacious & clean room w/ fridge, microwave, free wifi. Free breakfast, comfy bed, quiet. Stayed here for the Sedona Marathon; it's walking distance from the starting line. Got the cheapest room available and was pleasantly surprised at how nice it was. They even let me check out at noon instead of 11 to give me time to walk back and shower after the race (I just asked at breakfast).Location is great - easy to get to stuff, but not right in the middle of the more hectic and touristy parts of town. I highly recommend this hotel.
review_content_20: Well, the room is nice. Location great. I booked the room through Hotwire.com, that is another story. Hotwire's map & directions are sooooo wrong to get to this location.My family stayed here during labor day weekend. The front desk ladies were very friendly and polite. The room was suprising large and clean with a LCD tv and free wireless internet. The only downside was the microscopic bathroom. Overall, the experience was amazing for the price. Highly recommended.For Sedona, this hotel is a great value and in a decent location. The room was very clean and the staff friendly. The pool was also very nice, and warm too! The continental breakfast is a bit on the light side but the overall value of the hotel outweighed this somewhat minor inconvenience. I would definitely stay again!I didn't stay and wouldn't just because the reservation on site lady was so rude (9/2/12). I called twice within 10 minutes and the second time when I said I was inquiring about a room for tonight, she said, "what about it, I just talked to you". It doesn't matter if she talked to me 15 times - does it? We paid $75 more to stay somewhere else just to avoid having to deal with them.We made a reservation by phone for this accommodation for part of the 4th of July weekend, planning to stay here for two nights while we get out of the heat in the Phoenix metro area. We reserved with a credit card a suite with two rooms and two beds. This morning, the day before we were to check in, we received a call from the desk clerk saying that they were canceling our reservation because the clerk who booked the room made a mistake and three adults and two children under 12 couldn't stay in that room. And they could not provide us with a second room since they were completely booked. But neither he nor the manager, Noa BanBaber made any attempt to put us up at another hotel to rectify THEIR MISTAKE!" Instead, they took the easy way out and simply canceled our reservation and told us to go somewhere else. Which will be a near impossibility at this late date in that resort city on this holiday weekend. The manager said she "would look into why the mistake was made" as if that would solve the problem she created for us. The clerk who called this morning was extremely apologetic but the manager was extremely defensive and refused to even acknowledge that Days Inn had any obligation to us, the consumer, by accepting a reservation made in good faith. She bluntly told me that she and Days Inn had no obligation to us.......We stayed there a month ago and while a little tough to find, as it's in West Sedona, about 5 miles from uptown, it worked for us. Stopping for directions in one of those tourist info centers the people in front of us were told rooms start around $125 and we were only paying around $75. If we went back wouldn't hesitate staying there again.Apparently we had one of the best rooms in the property. The room was clean and fairly spacious. However, the bathroom was tiny. Free breakfast was OK (oatmeal, fruit, danishes). Linda @ the front desk was a sweetie and totally well-informed. I didn't like the threats printed out on table tents, in the form of menus of prices for various sizes of missing towels.

review_content: We've stayed at Las Posadas 4 times and really love this place! Each unit we stayed in had a gas fireplace, small kitchen area and was very clean and comfortable. The staff was always great and even gave us a discount for repeat business. They also ask ahead of time if anyone in the party had special food needs so that they could inform the chef for your breakfast each morning.  Counting the days until we can visit again!I really enjoyed my stay in Las Posadas, which is not far from Sedona. Like a number of other resorts and hotels in the area, it is actually in the Village of Oak Creek. Our unit was spacious and very clean, and the staff was very friendly and accommodating. The bathroom was huge and the king-size bed was very comfortable, and the suite had a sleeper sofa and the requisite microwave and small fridge, plus a Keurig coffee maker and coffee pods. Compared to chain hotels and resorts, this establishment as has a more quiet, secluded feel and is conveniently located near the first roundabout you reach on Route 179 on your way to Sedona from I-17. The complimentary breakfast in the dining hall was hearty, with tamales, egg, sausage, fresh fruit, yogurt, muffin, and granola. I would definitely recommend this place to friends planning to visit the Sedona/Oak Creek area.I'm only giving this place one star instead of zero because the facility itself was quiet and clean. It's unfortunate the staff is a COMPLETE nightmare.  A few days prior to arriving, I spoke to the concierge who informed me that check in was at 11am.  It was obviously a miscommunication because check in is not actually until 3pm.  When we arrived at 12:30 pm, we were greeted by a smug "front desk manager" named Britney.  AFTER taking my credit card, she informed us that check in was not until 3pm.  My boyfriend told her that we had planned our day based on the earlier check in time so if there was anything she could do to get us in a little sooner, we would really appreciate that.  She then smugly stated, "check in is at 3."  Knowing there was nothing we could do (even though it was their fault by telling us the wrong check in time) we decided to head out and enjoy the town until our room was ready.  She told us she would call us when the room was ready.  I then asked her what room we were in (for the simple reason that I wanted to drive by and see if we had a view) and she told me that they "cannot disclose that information" until we check in.  I said "um, ok".  She then says, "you are welcome to stay somewhere else"...basically TELLING US TO LEAVE.  I was stunned since there was NO REASON for her rudeness.  My boyfriend (who previously worked in the hotel business for 15 years) asked her to speak to the manager.The "hotel manager", John, (who we found out, is the owners son) came out in a pair of shorts, sneakers, and a half tucked in shirt.  My boyfriend very calmly explained what had just happened and instead of apologizing and trying to rectify the situation, the "manager" told us that she is an amazing employee and we must have done something to provoke her to act that way.  I guess Mommy and Daddy had to give him a "job" since he would obviously never make it in the real world with those "management" skills.  Being that half of our trip was ruined already, we decided to still stay there and not go through the hassle of trying to book another room somewhere else, last minute.  We waited until 3:45 for them to call us to tell us when the room was ready, as she had told us she would do.  We never got any call and just showed back up.  The next morning, the lobby/office is supposed to open at 8am.  We were not able to check out until 8:40am when Britney decided to make an appearance at her job. After our departure, we attempted to call the "manager" again, since he was conveniently not available in the morning when we left.  We got no answer and no return call to the message we left him.  4 days later, he finally called us.  He did apologize and told us they are having major staff problems at the hotel so I'm not sure why he was such a wimp in front of his little girlfriend at the front desk.  He said he would send us a free stay to give them another try.  A month later and we havent received anything or heard from them at all.  At this point, you couldn't PAY ME to stay there ever again. STAY FAR FAR AWAY FROM THIS PLACE!Our family loved our stay here.  First of all the staff was accommodating and nice we came in late and the front desk clerk walked us to our room.  The villa we stayed in was super clean and had a little kitchenette that came in handy.  It was really nice to wake up and walk over for a delicious breakfast every morning made by Chef Jeffrey.  The location was convenient.  We really enjoyed our time in the saltwater pool and spa.  The water in the pool was so soft.  We occasionally stopped by the office to grab a cookie (best cookie ever) and some refreshing ice tea. This is a charming little boutique bed and breakfast.  I highly recommend staying here.I love boutique hotels!  For the most part we had a great time staying here. I so wish I could give this place a 5.  Highlights:-  Great location. Away from the heart of downtown, but everything is in a very short driving distance- Property is well taken care of, up to date on decor- Rooms are a GREAT size and wonderful amenities! - TASTY breakfast!  Baked Cookies! - Condo style environment with a lot of the rooms =  quiet. Cons:- We chose the one room with the jacuzzi outside on the enclosed patio.  Before any love birds think this is a wonderful idea, be aware that the room you are in shares a wall with the kitchen.  The prep counter they use is backed up to your wall.  The kitchen staff comes in 5:00- 6:00 am to start to prep your tasty breakfast. The walls are thin and the noise echos cause the bfast hall is all tile flooring.  They were playing light music while they work, talking on the phone, laughing with each other (How dare they enjoy their jobs!? lol)... But honestly you HEAR it all.  If you like to sleep in until dawn, this room is NOT for you!)  This is the only room attached to the "main house" and the noise will go away after bfast hours.  We had a friendly chat to make them  aware but honestly what can you do to eliminate this 100%?  Ask them to stop making you a rockin bfast?  :) -  They were going through management changes when I visited.  My experience leading up to arrival was great, as the manager was a wonderful Sedona Concierge. We did not receive the same level of service once we got there.  In all fairness, they may have worked that out by now!My new husband and I loved it here. The room was stunning and even though we checked in after the office closed, we had ice in the freezer and cookies! The fireplace was stunning and the hottub was very relaxing... The only thing we would have changed is that we booked more than one night!This place was amazing!  The room was huge and had its own fireplace and balcony! The location was ideal as it was the first round about we hit (traveling from the south) and it was not too far from shops and restaurants.  Upon checking in they asked if we had any dietary restrictions for breakfast the next morning. We actually showed up early for breakfast but the girl was super accommodating. We had some fruit and yogurt. Again, our choice because we were early as we had to hit the road.This place was wonderful. We wish we had more time to spend here!We just returned from spending the weekend at Las Posadas.  It was very enjoyable and quiet.  The morning breakfast (included) was very tasty.  The staff were all friendly.  The units were really spacious.  We chose this inn as they do allow dogs ($25 fee).  It is not right in Sedona but rather, in The Village of Oak Creek which is just outside Sedona.  I like that it was a little out of town because it was so quiet.  I would totally return.  Oh, we had dinner across the road at Cucina Rustica.  Fantastic!I have never been to a bed and breakfast and this place made me fall in love with what we got. The location is 7 miles from the city center-not that big of a deal. It is located in a quiet peaceful area (although I think all of Sedona is like that). No problem with parking, we parked near our room. We went at the end of December-really cold but perfectly fine when hiking.About the room-very spacious, spotless, beautiful fireplace, loved the jacuzzi.We went on a weekday getting a discount. Jeff was amazing-first by phone he gave me advice and was even so nice as to type out a one page description of how to get to a certain hiking area by way of how the locals do it. I thought that was so nice! I found ALL staff to be friendly, accommodating, and more.  We did not always show up before the time they left (around 5) but they left the key on the front window. The breakfast was good and we enjoyed that. However I did not like the afternoon snacks, none of us ate them for the 2 nights we were there. That's ok, good thing we brought our own snacks.  If you ever go to Sedona, I highly recommend Las Posadas!We've had an amazing stay here! Was a little concerned about the cost at first but it's certainly worth it! Plenty of room, relaxing setting and a great location as it's a little away from the town of Sedona.  Would visit again!I love Las Posadas! We always stay there when we go to Sedona, and they never disappoint. The idea of a bed and breakfast turned me off at first, but this place was built to be a bed and breakfast. You don't feel like you are in a random person's house- it's private, cozy and comfortable. I love the fireplaces in each room, and breakfast has always been good. The staff is kind and accomodating, and you are in walking distance of some great dining options. One reccomendation, if you can reserve the room with the hot tub, it is absolutely PERFECT in the AZ winter nights.Las Posadas provided our hotel accommodations while in Sedona over this past weekend.  It was our first time staying there, and we are so glad we did!  Dorrie, the Office Manage ( I believe ), the Breakfast Chef ( included daily ) and Zenaida, the Cleaning Lady, were fabulous.  We stayed in a view room and enjoyed our Red Rock views and patio immensely.  The rooms are unique in that the feel is more like renting your very own private condominium studio - Not hotel-style at all!  We loved the open space feel of the entire unit and having the mini kitchenette is an absolute bonus.  Clean (not perfect) but very comfortable AND at an awesome value.  Looking forward to returning, especially once the pool is completed!  Thanks for a wonderful stay Las Posadas - See you again soon!Normally we like to stay at larger resorts but this time my wife suggested we try a smaller more intimate property.  She found Las Posadas and we fell in love with it immediately!  We have room to park our motorcycle trailer with a Jacuzzi outside the front door and a fireplace at the foot of the bed.  Our visit was wonderful and we will be back.Las Posadas is not a typical bed and breakfast. It is a cluster of small apartment-like dwellings.  Our room had a living room with a couch, TV, and small fridge and microwave. The bedroom was separate with a king size bed and spacious bathroom. The place is clean, modern, and new.  The location is great - technically not in Sedona but the adjacent town of Oak Creek Village about 7 miles from the central touristy area of Sedona. I prefer this location to central Sedona--plenty of shops and restaurants and access to main attractions.The breakfast was excellent. We were asked about dietary restrictions before our arrival and we told them we don't eat pork. However, both breakfast entres had pork our first morning. The chef, Austin, made us an excellent, improvised breakfast burrito which saved the meal for us. But the poor communication is why we gave it 4 stars and not 5.Las posadas was a great little suite to take in after a long night at a wedding.  Very nice, clean and quiet. We will definitely be coming back again!!!Great stay.  I am a fan of smaller, boutique places because they tend to weed out the riff-raff and you don't tend to get screaming kids.  Or my other favorite--the people who hog the deck chairs at the pool at 7am.  This place is completely tucked away, relaxed, and well appointed.  There are only 20 units but the grounds are pretty expansive.  Our Valencia room was at least 1000 square feet.  And we had our own little kitchen, living room, and outside patio.  Charming little place.  Only an 8 to 10 minute drive to Sedona.We, and many of our guests, stayed at Las Posadas in August for our wedding. It is a beautiful property with gorgeous villas and rooms, well decorated, spacious, etc. I rented a villa so that my bridesmaids and I would have lots of room to get ready, and it was perfect! It may have actually been about as big as my house, but much more luxurious. Dory is amazing and so are the rest of the staff. Breakfast was yummy the morning I was able to have it (missed it the first morning due to having to get up and go get our hair done). We are hoping to return for our anniversary!We went here for our anniversary last month.  It was wonderful! The staff is super friendly, and they knew it was our anniversary so they brought homemade truffles to our room.  We had the suite with the hot tub outside, and it was nice.  The hot breakfast in the morning was delicious.  The room was clean...we will be here again next year.We had a change of plans and I cancelled our reservation one month in advance and they charged us $75 to cancel.  You must read the fine print in their cancellation policy -it is not written as clear as it could be....  It states "Cancellations must be made 15 or more days prior to arrival date to receive a full refund"  It should not use the word "full refund" because there is no full refund.  Once you reserve here be sure not to cancel as you are charged a minimum of $75.   I read it quickly -my mistake but there is so much fine print to read and I have never had a hotel not give me a full refund for giving them one months notice. We hoped to stay at this hotel in the future but with this cancellation policy I'm not sure we would.  We have 2 little kids and traveling can be so unpredictable with children so we need hotels with better flexibility. I suggest to management to place on their website the following as I'm sure many others have fallen trap to this.  "If you cancel at any time you will be charged a minimum of $75 per room and there is no refund for cancellations within 15 days of your arrival."Slam. Dunk.  Terrific accommodations, beautifully maintained, comfy bed, gas fireplaces, red rock views, and a delicious breakfast.If you're deciding between here and someplace cheaper for a romantic getaway, go here.  It's worth every penny.
review_content_20: The best bed and breakfast I've ever been to. Very spacious and quiet. The fireplace was very helpful because it did get a little chilly outside. My favorite part was the bathrooms, loved the hot tub and the glass showers! Sedona is a magnificent place! Planning a trip back next year as well. Will be staying here againclean, friendly and a good value in the Sedona area.Worth the money! This place was quiet and very nice. My husband and I came for our first anniversary and loved it. We got the room with a full size hot tub and it was beautiful. We had a great time and will be back.This place is wonderful!  It's a B&B but not your typical inn. The rooms are big suites and the breakfast is gourmet!We timed it right (the first week in March) which is before high season. We got a lower rate, missed the crowds and the heat. Perfect for us.The location is more to the Village of Oak Creek end of Sedona so if you are driving up from Phoenix it's right off the first round about.Highly recommended!

review_content: We got a special wedding party rate at this hotel, and in spite of my FRANTIC "shopping around" on and offline, I couldn't find anything better that was close to the wedding venue (L'Auberge/$$$$$$$$$$)  Sedona is what it is, esp. during its busy season, and even the "cheap" places to stay might take a bite out of your budget.  With a week's vacation and TONS of stuff planned, we didn't want to spend too much on what we needed, which were clean, comfortable, basic accommodations, preferably with a pool and breakfast.  We got all that and MUCH more here at the Arabella.  Fast, friendly check in, perfect balcony room overlooking the courtyard (I would insist on balcony over ground level, unless stairs are a problem for you) and an AWESOME view of the red rocks which was second to none!!  We arrived on a Friday evening, checked in, and really didn't spend too much time at the hotel, as we were meeting up with family, but did take advantage of the main courtyard pool (COLD in the morning!!) and perfectly acceptable breakfast.  Our two night stay in our double queen room (wanted King, but it wasn't available) was comfortable and problem free.  We didn't check out the spa or the VERY recommended Elote Cafe, but our time was limited.  I would definitely recommend a stay here, as it's perfectly located, convenient, and quite comfortable...  We moved on to another location after the wedding, just a little farther outside of town, only because we're EXTREME cheapos, but this was a FINE home base for us for our first few days in Sedona!!This place is fine.  Not at all overpriced or dirty overall.  Although we do have a tiny bandaid on the wall.   Himmmm.  No bother.Not sure about other horrid reviews.  We drive here from Phx.  We've actually been here before.  Last year?  I am pretty sure we have same room.  250.  The check in gal was slightly in edge.  But accommodating.It's quiet here now- end of August. Elote is closed for vacation until September 2nd.  When it's open it is much more "festive".  I appreciate the many different types of people we meet here -from France, Germany, Mexico.  It's  awesome!  This hotel had to have been built in the 1960s.  I think some rooms but not all rooms have been remodeled. We are in a remodeled one.  Perhaps the older ones are what all the smelly reviews are about.  The decor in the room is new retro 60s style.  Cool.  We do not appreciate the jet bathtub.  It just doesn't seem clean.  I can't imagine they deep clean it so - not necessary.I don't really appreciate the soaps & shampoos in the refillable wall containers.  But it works.  The little fridge is good.  The beds are a bit firm.  Clean white cotton linen and shiny satin bedspread.  Pillows are extra great.  Balcony with little table and 2 chairs is nice.It has an old fashioned Mad Men feel to it.  That is why I like it, I guess.  I love how th main pool is the center of all of the original rooms.  Makes me feel as if I am back in the day gazing at the same sky and beautiful mountains the 60s folks did.  It is actually neat!  Breakfast is acceptable.  Cereals, cold milk (almond milk too).  Fresh bananas and apples.  Hard boiled eggs. Quality whole wheat bread.  Bagels - just the cruddy plain kind.  Butter packets, cream cheese cups.  Jams and syrups.  Make your own waffle griddle.  Sausage patty was pretty dang salty.  Scrambled eggs are just the reconstituted kind and they taste like what they are.  The lady watching over everything was kind and helpful.We really enjoy the pool.  We wished the big pool was heated.  It is just nippy.  Hot tub is great.  Everything is clean.  Staff is always on the go cleaning and maintaining everything.  The pool guy and towel lady made sure the pool area was ready for guests.All in all, it is worth $150.We will come again.Stayed here two nights for Fourth of July weekend.It's conveniently located on AZ-179 on the way to Uptown Sedona. The rooms seem to have been renovated. They have three or four buildings where rooms have balconies. But I was stuck in a room on the ground floor in the main building. The reception is literally right around the corner. But it's just a room to sleep in as I'm doing lots of hiking up all the amazing red rock formation.The book is booked through "Rocketmiles" which would award me 1,500 Asia Miles (as does with many airlines) and the rate is $119 before tax. The room (Room 1125) itself is more than adequate. Plenty of lighting. two huge lamps on the nightstand, another one on the writing desk with pull-out working table. 42" TV. The bathroom is hilarious. It's got a wheeler accessible shower space with a commote like you see at the hospital. The water in the shower is not hot enough and water pressure needs improvement. The A/C is running well. The complimentary breakfast is nothing to call home about. Hordes of people are hogging the toaster with four slots and the single waffle machine. The sausage patties are way too salty that I feel I have enough sodium for the whole week. The scrambled egg has a texture of mashed potato and does not taste like egg. All I had for breakfast was a muffin and a cup of coffee from the lobby. The coffee a the breakfast room is too watery. To make the long story short: skip the breakfast and go somewhere else to eat.Wifi is free but not the strongest. Complimentary bike for sightseeing. Walking distance to an OK convenience store (practically next door).Overall it's not a bad place to stay. It's adequate for sleeping. It's clean. Staff is super friendly and accommodating.BEAUTIFUL rooms!!! First off, we cant seriously find out how to turn the lights on...seriously. No knobs, no light switch. Nothing!!!! Called the front desk, he said he would come down and find the switch on the lamps....ahhhhhh...they are on the CORDS!!!Weird!!!The room is nice, roomy and cozy........great place for luggage. Huge windows to enjoy the view...Very happy with the room. Quiet. Nice.Looking outside our patio there is a fire pit going. Soooo nice.See photos I posted up above....awesome place!!Would recommend!!!!!Will be back to stay here again.Great location with average accommodations. Continental breakfast is subpar but better than nothing. Front desk is very nice and helpful. Rooms are outdated and nothing great.I love this hotel. When I arrived they upgraded me to a deluxe room at the trailhead of the mountain. My large balcony had an amazing view of the red rocks. The pool and spa are great. The continental breakfast actually had hot food. Free mountain bikes to borrow. My room was huge with a nice sized desk to work at. Spa top in my room felt great after a hike and having the amazing Elote Cafe connected just made it all the better. Room was super clean, bed was super comfy and I cannot wait to come back. You get a lot of bang for your buck so to speak.We checked into the Arabella last night randomly and we are very pleased! The room is very clean and the beds were super comfortable! Thank you Jason for being so accommodating! And thank you to the entire staff! We will definitely be back.Great hotel of you are traveling with dogs. They had a small dog area to walk them (although grass and more lighting would have been nice). But everyone was very friendly and helpful. Room was very clean and quiet. Towels weren't super soft but bed was pretty comfortable. Room seemed updated and cable was really Nice. The temperature seemed really hard to control in the room. You have to choose heat or air but if you leave the heat on you wake up during the night burning hot. Doesn't seem to stay at the right temperature. We didn't get much sleep because of that. Only other thing we didn't like was they called a cab for us and some greasy guy in an unmarked car showed up and randomly charged us $10 for a 2 minute car ride (no meter so he just made up a price). I would definitely stay here again when the weather is nicer so we don't need to worry about the heater.*Hot rooms *Rude staff*Filthy Room*Dirty room*Filthy bathtubWe took a trip to Sedona for the Celebration of Spring egg hunt event. Check in wasn't until 4 pm, but we figured that maybe by chance the room might be ready as the checkout times for the hotel is 11 a.m.We pulled into the hotel premises at around 2:45 pm hopeful that we might be able to check in. I walked up to the front desk, at this time the lobby was clear and asked the tight lipped front desk woman if our room was ready. She looked up my information and said flatly  "No, check in is at 4 o clock" Okay, I thought to myself, I "tried"... Our children both under the age of four were very tired and cranky at this point, so rather than try to kill some more time sightseeing, we just drove around the corner to the Circle K next door to pick up some water. Traffic was extremely congested this day, so we decided to pull back into the hotel parking lot and ended up driving around what seems to be either  a rundown seedy motel or apartment complex directly next to the Arabella Hotel. What was striking about this motel is that it is almost exactly the same color as the Arabella. What was also striking were two oily, dirty women sharing what looked to be a glass pipe from the balcony walkway above. From there we drove to the other side the Arabella, we decided to just park with the A/C running and just wait it out. While parked we noticed a couple of the hotel maids stumble out of one the rooms, and when I say "stumble out" that's exactly what I'm saying, they looked like they'd fallen asleep in a field of poppies ala Wizard of Oz. At 4 p.m. I walked back into the hotel, this time there was a long line of guests that would be checking also. A few of them were told that there rooms were not ready, that it might be until 6 p.m. before there room was available. One of the front desk clerks suggested to one of these guests that they should try waiting in front of the Elote Cafe, he told her that this was "THE BEST Mexican restaurant in all of the state," and "that past 5 p.m. the lines form very quickly that you can't get a table". He then told her "go wait in line in front of the cafe over there, and hey if your room becomes available, I'll wave at you." But that was all a ruse, as the Elote Cafe doesn't open until 5 p.m. and it was only 4:07 p.m. Ten minutes later I saw this lady sadly walk back to her parked car. When we finally made it to our room, our first impression was HOW HOT the temperature in the room was... the a/c was completely shut off. When the Arabella says a "room with a view" they mean a room facing direct sunshine with an overview of other people lounging in the pool, oh and the highway and then maybe the hill behind all that mess. W got the a/c going and I decided to take a shower, it was an uncomfortable shower after I discovered hair lodged in certain areas. The curtain and tub was filthy.The minifridge had smudges all over it, and on the inside were two tall cans of beer, that were near full. The carpet had random wet spots in it.  The whole room was just disgusting, hot, stuffy and beyond uncomfortable. To add to all this the walls were painted a depressing yellow, like a giant tobacco stain. We decided to cut our losses ($214.00) and after 2 hours we packed up and drove back to our home in  Phoenix for a good night's sleep.*Hot rooms *Rude staff*Filthy Room*Dirty room*Filthy bathtubI flip flopped on 3 or 4 stars but affordability and amenities won me over. I made reservations by phone about a month before our stay (our 5 year wedding anniversary), we were bringing our dog so we wanted to be sure it was truly pet friendly. The woman I spoke to was helpful. I wanted a King bed but she stated the only dog friendly room left was Queen. I took it knowing I could cancel my reservation 2 days before my reserved date. I recieved a confirmation email. A few hours later she sent me another email stating they could get us in a King room and they'd give it to us at the Queen price!We checked in right at check in time (4:00). There was a line but it went quickly. My check in went smoothly. There was free tea and water in the lobby. We found parking right outside our room. We stayed in Room 126. The room was nice. It was mostly clean, we noticed some trail mix pieces under the desk. Otherwise no complaints. The door to the room looked like it was pried into at some point. Mini fridge. Great view. Patio with table and chairs. One weird thing was we got complimentary shampoo and lotion but no soap. (They gave us some when they cleaned the room the next day but forgot to refill the tissue dispenser). We kept meaning to stop back at the lobby and ask for some but kept forgetting so we ended up buying some. The bed was comfortable,  toilet and shower worked! Yay!Luckily I brought ear plugs. Late at night and early morning there is alot of noise. You can hear people upstairs running around. Little kids yelling outside. And they make us sign a noise policy if our dog barks! My dog was far better behaved than these kids. Trash (chip bags, French fry containers) was left in the grass of the courtyard but they don't want our dog going out there.  Makes me laugh. They have a small dirt area by our room for dogs to do their thing with a free poop bag dispenser. On to the free breakfast served 7-10am served in the back of Elote restaurant. Bagels, scrambled and hardboiled eggs, danish, cereal, apples, sausage, oatmeal, make your own waffle station. Juice bar, coffee, etc. The waffles were great. It took me forever to hunt down butter though. I asked one worker and she pointed to the drink dispenser?? I found out someone spilled milk in the butter so they were getting more. Lori, the woman I assume was running breakfast was frantic the whole time. Yelling loudly at workers. Moving/carrying around chairs and tables. She couldn't find the toaster. I want a relaxing quiet breakfast,  not some OCD hovering over my table ready to pounce on my plates to clean up. We didn't go back the second morning. There is a really awesome trail behind the hotel called Marg's Draw. Great views from up there. We hit that trail right after check in. Great place to watch the sunset. We skipped eating at Elote because they are not pet friendly. And the hostess seemed rude. Sorry for bothering you.Beware that parking gets tight between 4pm and 10p while the restaurant is running. They need to designate parking spots for guests only.The pool and spa were open. Free ice. Soda machines. Circle K a short walk away if you need something. I would definitely stay here again even with all the little things that bugged me. It was a great price for a decent place. It's a short drive to town. Very convenient.Enjoyed our stay here, the breakfast was great, swimming pool was awesome, we slept very well here. Can't wait to return next summer!!Loved this hotel. Would stay again in a heart beat. Clean nice rooms. Very friendly staff. Good breakfast buffet with a great view of the red rocks. We walk from our hotel to the restaurants and shops.This place had a weird and old smell to it. The staff was friendly enough. But I was suppose to get a balcony room as discussed with the girl on the phone, but didn't. They gave me the smallest and cheapest room AND I got charged for a balcony room. They did reimburse me, after making a bunch of calls. Check in was at 4pm. Not a minute earlier, unless you had a nicer room. It sucked waiting there and everyone else that had the balcony/courtyard rooms getting early check in, when we were just told no one gets an early check in. The breakfast was disgusting. I will never go back.Julia Kaiser. Asst. General Manager, made our stay here wonderful.  Julia took the time to personalize our stay and really made it special.  I look forward to staying here again in the future. Sedona is a one of a kind place to visit. Editing my review as the new room we stayed in did not have towels. Not sure how this can be missed but it was an important one.   Need to do better next time.I found this place on Expedia and it was such a disappointment!! First time I have not been happy! We thought we were getting a room with a little patio and they put us in the old hotel above the little pool no access to outside unless u walk down a stairwell the smelled like cigarette smoke masked with bad air freshener. My 4 year old grabbed the railing in the stairwell to walk down the stairs and it fell off the wall, the room was super hot like the air turned off in the middle of the night . I had an extra night booked and we cancelled it and almost went home , thank god we found a different place!!The customer service here is by far the worst I have ever experienced in a very long time. I did not stay here but I didn't need to, because I knew exactly how I would be treated if I did. I booked online and arrived at 11am by the off chance a room would be available early, this is not uncommon practice but immediately I was brushed off by a "check in is at 4pm." Ok fine, maybe since it's a small town they don't have the staff to handle check in's and check out's quickly. She asked us to come back at 1-2pm, and maybe something would be ready. Ok, we'll check again at 2pm. At 2pm, we got the response, "No, it won't be ready until 4pm." Sigh, but fine, we'll check in then. Then 4:15pm came around and still no room. Not even a sorry, or we'll make it up to you. Not a modicum of customer service just a blank and monotone response from the front desk that it wasn't ready and there was not a time in sight of when it would be.  The big problem with this is not just the above, but I had booked to stay for a wedding. The wedding started at 5pm. At 4:38p I called back and calmly asked again if the room was ready, no it wasn't, again not a sorry in sight. And that was the straw that broke this little camel's back as I asked them how they would make this right, their only response was a 20% discount, which in my opinion not good enough, for making us late to a wedding and without the ability to have a room to get ready in. Without a seconds thought I immediately cancelled the reservation, and told them I shouldn't be penalized for it with their late cancellation fee's because what we had endured up until that point was pretty ridiculous. Their response you ask? Ok, we'll cancel. This is exactly how companies act when they believe they don't depend upon the money's incoming from guests or they have so much business because of their location, they don't need to cater to a customer. So friends, I can't stress this enough...Even if the price/location seems attractive, do not book. Even if it's the only hotel room in town, use Airbnb instead, you're money will be better spent and you'll meet much nicer and accommodating people.First off we got the room for $50, 5 nights from a time share in Maui, so we didn't expect amazing but did expect better!! First day killed a black widow. Second day 2 roaches. Third day a huge brown super almost landed in my lap and there are lizards every where, I can deal with lizards, not bugs!!! Staff didn't care! The bed was mushy! The bathroom needs new seal... We left a $5 tip each day yet little things like sink not washed out was irritating. Would not stay here again!Originally this hotel looked decent and a good deal for the price, but during the night my wife had allergic reaction to something in the bed. Had trouble breathing. She went out side and started feeling fine. went back inside to go to sleep at about 2 in the morning and woke up at 5:30 with her lungs really hurting. The hotel switched rooms for the 2nd night but could not really enjoy the day with out any sleep. We met friends there so the day without sleeping the night before affected all 4 of our retreat for the weekend. The other room was much improved and appreciated, however the day after that night was to do a short hike and travel back home, so our whole weekend was impacted from this. The manager took off half of the first night, which I thought when she said half off that she meant the whole bill. To top things off the breakfast was lousy, eggs were watery and not much available. There is a reason this hotel seems cheap! it is!!! Worst experience with a hotel ever.  To add final insult to injury; Since my wife originally booked the trip with her card it was charged the morning of the planned stay, My card was charged for the bill when we got there and it was charged a 2nd time to reflect the reduction  in cost on the new bill. So we have three charges on our accounts showing pending, so over $700 in charges until the bank clears the correct bill, which is now about $200 for the two nights after $65 reduction.  We assume the allergic reaction was due to a cat in the room but not sure, could be some cheap cleaner that they used. Anyway any decent person would have just voided the entire bill. The manager made it seem like a burden that she had to deduct some money from our bill. This is my first review this negative and believe me it takes a lot to get me to talk this badly about a business, but they need to take better care of their customers. I was close to taking my wife to the hospital that night, but the Benadryl curbed it enough to get through the night. Serious health risk for us to stay here again.. And the beds were hard, pillows soft which also made sleeping uncomfortable. no one in our group got a good nights sleep..After writing review, I was contacted by the manager. I had assumed the person who helped me was the manager. The manager apologized for his staff and credited me for the bill. After experience with the manager (Chris), it is only fair to give him credit for making things right.We had a great stay. The rooms are good and clean. Beds are comfortable. Staff is very helpful and friendly. They provided information, maps, etc. and were very approachable. Breakfast and cafeteria can be improved in terms of the food served, cleanliness and space during peak times. We did the hike that starts right behind the hotel and it was beautiful. Views are gorgeous. Overall a comfortable stay.Great location,close to all the shops as well as the best Mexican restaurant I've been to. The room was a good size for a family of 4.we arrived early for check in and a room was not ready for us but they upgraded us to right across from the garden and pool,it was great! The breakfast was delicious with lots of hot food options. I would Definetly recommend this hotel.
review_content_20: My boyfriend and I stayed here for the weekend. Love the place, however I accidentally left my work cell phone in Rm 120 but no one turned it in. I am definitely going back to Sedona but this time we might choose a different location.Oh man!!  Had to get the place on expedia because Hiltons all sold out.  First mistake..We get here and the front desk old guy is bad mouthing expedia to some other customers.  Ok, whatever.  We get in the rooms and the curtains are torn up, yes, ripped and torn the the carpet is old and smelly plus the kicker?  The rooms stinks of cigarette smoke!  We both smelled it and it was bad.  We tell the front desk old guy and he is surprised that we are surprised like this the norm.  He says in a pre practiced way "I'll make a note of it" if that didn't insult me I don't know what would?  He could care less of our complaints!  This dump reminds me of a dumpy old hotel room from the 70's outside of las Vegas or Disneyland!  The girl at the front desk was very nice but the old guy just didn't care and it showed.  Time to retire!  Please see my picture of the expensive room with torn curtains..  This is a first, Im a pilot and spend a lot of time in hotels and I have to say that this is a first.  Congrats!  DUMP!  The rooms were not all that clean either, sink area, tub, bathroom etc..All just not what I expected!I really don't know what to say about all these bad reviews, we stayed last weekend and our room was big, clean and quiet. The grounds were fine and the staff was more than helpful in accommodating us considering either I or expedia screwed our dates up. The beds were really comfortable and the pillows I wanted to steal they were so good. Our room was very cool temp wise and didn't have any kind of cigarette smell like others have complained of, maybe we just got a good room and lucked out. The restaurant Elote was amazing!! But be ready for at least an hour wait if not two.Staff seemed a little preoccupied always, the room was extremely noisy (you could hear the people walking above pretty badly), it was a dog friendly hotel which we needed (but their idea of the dog area was a bleak red dirt lot with lots of weeds and sticker burrs, not great for furry friends). The hotel room was dog friendly in that the floor was tile. The bed was soft and pillows were decent. There was a continental breakfast complete with waffle maker which came in handy for a quick breakfast in the morning before going out for adventures. There was a courtyard with pool and lots of lounge chairs which we did not use because it was "no dogs allowed." Let's just say they allow pets to stay here but it's not "dog friendly."Let me start by saying I was not able to stay here due to the horrible front desk and reservation service. As this is a pet friendly hotel, I of course wanted to confirm as I have a large dog. The first time I called I sat on hold for 25 minutes until I finally hung up. I tried again the next day and got right through, but when I said I wanted to make a reservation, I was greeted with "Ummm....I can't help you with that right now because I have a lobby full of people".  After Being caught off guard I then asked if they could call me back so I could book, which he agreed to in an annoyed manner. To this day I have not received a call back.While I did read some negative reviews as to their level of service, I was still willing to give it a shot due to the price, however, I am thinking that if they are incapable of taking a reservation or returning a phone call then I am glad I didn't have the chance to waste my money.Great remodeled rooms. Awesome staff. Beautiful room views!!! For the price this was the best. El Lote Caffe it's across from the room. Excellent food within walking distanceOur room was comped for 4 days, which is why we stayed there.  Mixed reviews from us.  We were really scared to stay here after reading all the yelp reviews (although to be fair, this hotel gets better reviews on other websites).  In short, the property is not sketchy or horrible.  The courtyard is really quite nice, which several areas with tables and chairs, a firepit, flowers.  The rooms are okay...our had some weird plaster stuff going on on the walls, but it was clean (minus the dead bugs in the bathroom light).  Unlike many reviewers, I did not find our bed to be comfortable.  The actual bedding was cheap feeling and there was a plastic-rubbery cover under the sheets, I guess to protect the mattress?  It was noisy and uncomfortable.  Our room never got really chilly, although we had the AC running almost always, but it was fine.  The AC unit wasn't noisy, as other people have claimed.  We had no trouble with the front desk staff, except for a mix-up on the last day where we had housekeeping knocking on our door and the front desk calling, all to find out when we were leaving after they had already approved a late check out.  Housekeeping missed our room the first day, they just didn't come, and I'm not sure they would have come subsequent days if I hadn't reminded them or the front desk.  Really basic service from them.  The fridge in the room didn't work, it kept getting warmer then colder, eventually ruining all the food we took and leaking all over the floor.  The hotel was really good about us bringing our dogs and the hotel's pet area is adequate.  As other reviewers have mentioned, it's a dirt area with some rocks and benches.  It's not a grassy dog park and it doesn't purport to be, it was fine.  My husband went to breakfast the first day, it was basic non-brand-name, lower quality foods.  We did not return.  I flat out refused to swim in the pool the first day, when the pump wasn't running and there was debris all over the pool, plus tissues at the bottom (gross).  Also, the tiles on the sides of the pool are black with dirt, suntan lotion, dust, etc...I talked to one of the staff about it the following morning and he seemed surprised about the state of the pool the prior evening and said regarding the tiles, "Yeah, I need to get to that."  By the time we returned several hours later, the water looked cleaned up but the tiles were still totally gross.  In short, this stay would have cost $700 for the 4 days we were there (inclusive of the pet fee of $25/night).  Had this room not been comped, we would have been really upset with the quality.   I feel like a hotel charging $150 should have a pretty decent breakfast (if they're going to offer it), consistent housekeeping services, clean facilities everywhere, high thread count bedding.  Our stay was more like a hotel that charges $75-95/night.  It was like a La Quinta that had been refurbished a few years ago and was now showing the wear, not completely horrible but not great either.This review is for the customer service only.  When we arrived, we were told they did not have rooms for us due to plumbing problems in the room. It was a terrible situation and of course, we were not happy. The Assistant GM, Julia, took fantastic care of us and set up accommodations at another hotel. I was impressed with her genuine care and concern to make sure we still enjoyed our visit to Sedona even though we were disappointed that we couldn't stay at the Arabella. Outstanding service!They let us big both my dogs for a $50 pet fee...$25 each pet. They also have a small dog park, which isn't fenced but it's nice to have a spot to walk your dog. We had a room with a view and it was beautiful! It was really nice having breakfast in the morning. Staff was friendly. You have to share you balcony with your neighbor, which makes your room seem a little less private.I checked in my wife and kids at around 3:30 and Ken the front desk guy was the biggest prick I have ever met. Those of you that know me know that I'm a pretty cool guy and normally dont let shit bother me. Well he treated me like shit twice. Im so pissed that I'm already hecking out at its 7:30pm. I will never ever stay here or recommend anyone to stay here.

review_content: What a quaint, cozy place and after all the years, I have visited one of my favorite places on earth....I find this jewel. I will be back again and again and again. Ahhhh....just saw Jackie, the owner's wife with their two of three Bassett Hounds - Ollie & Dexter!!  Can't say enough good things about this wonderful hideaway!  I look forward to many more retreats to this peaceful place. Oh!  And don't forget the breakfast!  Delish...Arizona style!!This place rules. Yes, as some reviewers have mentioned, some little touch ups could be done in rooms to make them seem a little newer (cracks in the walls and such). However, those very minor things were nothing in comparison to how incredible everything else at El Portal was. Being from the Old Pueblo (that's Tucson, for you newbies to the AZ), I grow tired of hokey faux-Southwest decor, so I was pleased to see nothing hokey about this hotel. El Portal more closely resembles a B&B than a hotel, as they serve breakfast in the morning from 8-10 and offer complimentary snacks in the late afternoon/early evening. They also keep their little kitchen stocked with coffee (if you can dodge a wrench you can dodge a...WAIT...I mean, if you can push a button, you can stand to make your own K-Cup coffee), soda, hot water, wine, and hot chocolate. The property itself is beautiful with the interior main house having very sturdy wooden fixtures, and the main courtyard filled with tables and chairs to relax, as well as a large fire pit. We stayed in the Arts and Crafts room (#4), and loved the fact that our room had its own courtyard that our German Shepherd, Rose, could enjoy. They also gave us a little dog basket filled with dog treats made at a local pet bakery, dog bags (you know for the business side of things), a couple dog blankets, and a towel. Our room also had both a standalone shower and a whirlpool tub, which was a bit difficult for my bf to figure out, so some help on that front would have been cool upon check in. There was also a fireplace in our room, which we totally would have used if it had been cooler outside during our stay. There was a small fridge in our room as well, which was wonderful for us to store a few snacks in. The sheer amount of space and privacy in the room was fantastic and holy smokes I loved the bed. It was soo comfortable, and huge. Teri was awesome, as was owner Steve. Both were knowledgeable about the area and loved our dog, Rose. We did have breakfast in the morning, and my bf loved his omelet. I had the pancakes and I was stuffed after just one of them. Overall, awesome stay, friendly people, and beautiful property. :)Loved this pet-friendly place, and like Steve the owner, said on his website, you'll leave saying, "I wish I had more time to spend here!" We stayed for a weekend with not one, but two large doggies, and the rooms are spacious, immaculate, and luxurious in a low-key way. I loved the peace and quiet. If you like expensive modern style hotels via loud Las Vegas party rooms this place is NOT for you. But if you like Southwest decor, Navajo, Dine design-inspired robes in the guest closet, California arts and crafts furniture, the place is charming. Friendly and accommodating staff who aren't in your face all the time, the El Portal was perfect. Animal lovers rejoice! Yes, you have to go to the Great Room to get coffee, snacks etc. but why would you want to stay inside when there's beauty all around you? The courtyard is serene, with a fire pit at night, but with only a weekend to spare, we were so happy to step out of our little patio area and see all the stars in the cloudless night sky. So great to get away from NYC! Loved the bath toiletries, a luxurious soak in the tub after a hike. Can't wait to come back!What a fantastic place hidden away I didn't even know this place was here . It's a perfect destination spot located steps away from the action but yet peaceful . The fire pit was a special feature I loved sitting out there . We had the green room it was fantastic gorgeous and had a robe I would love to have and a blanket I want too ! The rooms get pitch black and makes for a good sleep. The beds are cozy the pillows were nice but a little low for me . I did hear a sound like someone was walking around the room on the wood floor. It was interesting . Thanks for the trip we will be back again really soon !My husband and I found this hotel and made it out vacation destination. We drove all the way from SF Bay Area and it was worth it! This hotel was nothing short of amazing. Plus our two Boston pups had a great time as well.There are already several great reviews for this place so I won't bore you by repeating the accurate comments but I do want to add my 2 cents to their rating.I had the pleasure of chatting with Steve, the owner, about the impetus for this place.  It was our first getaway with our dog in tow and it was the pet friendly experience that attracted my interest.  I love Peter K.'s comment that this "is a Resort for Dogs that allows humans."  They really do have a great little hide-away for folks traveling with their dog who want to feel welcome (dogs and humans).We only stayed for a couple of days but plan to "pop in" more often now that we know about this place.  The only bad thing about rating them so high is that others are going to find out about this awesome gem!At first I was in love with the hotel. It's beautiful with such a cozy cottage like vibe. Very homey and welcoming & the breakfast is wonderful. & as I continued my visit I found that not only were the neighbors staying in the rooms next to me shockingly rude, but as was the staff. They hounded my grandmother about the payment for the hotel, which was at first completely understandable, as you HAVE to pay for what you've received, & we definitely intend to and will. But they have not only made shockingly rude comments about how they "want us out" & have left notes on our door & are even starting to harass me & my sister, it's starting to get ridiculous. They threatened the police. We are or trying to rob them of anything & will not go without paying. This homey environment quickly turned very hostile & I am now very uncomfortable with my stay here.Hidden gem of small hotel with the feel of a bed and breakfast. Located in lower Sedona and sweetly  secreted behind Los Abrigados Resort and Tlaquepaque Arts & Crafts Village,  this stuccoed villa boasts an arts and crafts dining room with large timber rafters, unique iron fixtures and hardware and spacious,  well appointed rooms. Our room boasted views of sunrise and sunset views off nearby red bluffs and cheerful bird songs each morning from the enclosed, vine sheltered courtyard below us.  Breakfast was authentic Mexican/Southwest and freshly made - best huevos rancheros I've ever had! Steve the owner/creator was eager to share stories on how they envisioned and built the hotel, or quick to sketch out a map to interesting sites,  shops or drives nearby. We will come back!What an incredible place! Every suite is beautiful (we stayed in three) and our dog was thrilled to receive her own basket of blankets, baggies and treats.This trip to Sedona was a long-awaited and greatly anticipated getaway for my husband and me. We quickly discovered that staying at El Portal is like visiting relatives who really like you. We were introduced to -- and warmly greeted by -- staff members on arrival. It was made clear that we would be provided with anything that would make our stay more comfortable. We needed only to ask.I discovered El Portal while researching Sedona hotels that would allow us to bring our dog. They not only allowed the dog, but catered to her and her needs. Our room was adjacent to the Dining/Great room, and our girl slipped out the door every chance she got. An aging Therapy Dog, she wanted to meet everyone:  adults, children, other dogs, and the lady who made the awesome bacon every morning.  There was no admonishment to control our dog -- only gentle petting until we came to fetch her. Next time we take her to visit, I'll replace her ID tag with one that says, "I'm Cassie. Please return me to Room #__."I loved our private patio & garden, where I spent hours relaxing with a good book and my dog while my husband played golf. All three of us enjoyed sitting out by the fire pit in the evenings, which provided an almost indescribable serenity. The cost of staying at El Portal exceeded our usual hotel budget but was oh, so worth it!Stayed here for our anniversary. It was really beautiful and felt like you were staying at someone's rustic house. The room was gorgeous. They have campfires every night that you can meet and socialize with other hotel guests. Really a different experience and had a very warm feel. The only downside was they didn't have a pool and the crowd was a lot older than us. A great place to stay if you want an authentic az experience though.Stayed here in March for a solo trip of self-inflection and relaxation. They are super friendly as everyone has pointed out, and I love the rustic and charming vibe of the grounds. I was in the Molesworth suite which is in the hallway nearest the dining area. The floors can be a bit echoey so I heard the comings and goings of those staying in the room next to me. Not a huge deal since I was by myself but had this been a romantic trip it might have been a bit more irksome. I agree with a previous reviewer that they could spruce up their technology, but on the other hand most folks don't come to Sedona to watch T.V. in their room. The bathtub was amazing but I wish the shower had a covering of some type as the window faces the outside. Would definitely return.The best way to describe this place is that it is a Resort for Dogs that allows humans to stay as well.Having two Golden Retrievers, finding dog-friendly hotels and restaurants is always a challenge for my girlfriend and I whenever we vacation out of town.  El Portal Sedona offered an amazing spot for our four-legged children and us as well as a few other perks.The hotel itself has only 12 full-service suites, so it is a combination of a luxury hotel and a bed and breakfast.  As soon as we checked into our building, there was a dog-welcome package in our suite with a packet full of various dog-friendly restaurants, parks and emergency contacts.  Every suite in this hotel is unique with it's own design, set-up and amenities.  We booked the Flat Rock Hickory room which had it's own backyard (for the dogs) as well as an old-fashioned clawfoot bathtub (which the girlfriend absolutely love).  The backyard attached to the room itself was also very spacious where both the lady and I could relax while the dogs were running around and playing.  The room was so nice we didn't want to leave it for most of the day.The hotel is independently owned and comes with several unique features, one of which is the alcohol/drink bar.  There is a full stock of wine, beer, tea, coffee and soft drinks inside the central building of the resort that is based on the honor system; hotel management allows guests to help themselves to the available drinks as long as each guest writes down their suite number to the drink they take.  This would not be possible at any major chain, and another feature that really endeared to us.Another big perk to this Dog Resort is the central courtyard which all of the suites attach to.  In the evenings, all the guests of the hotel and their four-legged companions come to the central courtyard and hangout by the iron-cast fire-pit in the middle.  The hotel staff leaves around 7pm, but they also ensure a truck full of firewood is available for the guests.  We went out around 7:30pm after dinner, brought a few bottles of wine and our two Golden pups.  Nearly all 12 guests were out as well, sharing wine, stories and allowing all of our dogs to meet and play with each other.  It was one of the most pleasant vacation experiences my lady and I had with this close community feel and bonding with other dog owners.  We met four other dog-owning couples in this communal gathering that we still keep in touch with to this day.The only downside is the price.  There is a premium fee for each suite ($279 dollars for one night for our room), however you are paying for much more than just your room.  This is our go-to spot for lodging anytime we are in Sedona, and we recommend this place to all of our friends to stay even if they are not dog owners.  I have never been to a hotel/resort that had just a small community and closeness feel as El Portal Sedona.  This place fits in perfectly with the tranquil and welcoming nature of Sedona itself.My girlfriend and I stayed two nights in the Molesworth (room #2). All I can begin to say about our experience at El Portal is "WOW. This place is awesome!" The hotel is located off Portal Drive on the east side of Sedona near all of the shops and restaurants (literally short walking distance to all of them). You have your own private parking area right outside the establishment, and a parking pass, which made us feel very important.Our room was extremely spacious, with a King-sized bed, a huge couch, flat screen TV, mini-fridge, and the best bathroom I have ever experienced in a hotel/resort. The tile work in the separate shower was exceptional. There was lots of natural light from the big windows and amazing tile in the main room. It felt like a MASSIVE studio apartment.As for the staff, every single time we would leave to go out, the staff made sure to engage in pleasant conversation with us. We filled them in on all of our travels, and they made recommendations of their own. It really made the experience feel like we were staying at a good friend's house instead of a hotel. Additionally, the outdoor area was pleasant, with nice grass, chairs surrounding a fire pit, and the sound of birds chirping in the distance.Another great perk is the "honor system" for snacks, food, etc. Instead of room service, the establishment has a book where guests can sign in, using the "honor system" to take whatever they want from the kitchen (drinks, snacks, etc.). This worked out well when we needed that emergency bottle of wine at night.All in all, we will definitely be back at El Portal during our next visit. There is no other place like it and we would feel cheated staying anywhere else, given the location, the luxury, and the exclusivity that we felt there.It had been some time since I was able to get away on holiday.  Searching for a pet friendly hotel, (my four legged child is a great dane.  kinda can't sneak him in anywhere) I stumbled upon El Portal.  I had planned on only staying one night but extended my stay for another night.  Not only is the hotel absolutely magical and wonderfully pet friendly, the people are so lovely and full of suggestions.  I will definitely book a longer stay next time.This place was amazing from start to finish. Very warm and cozy and the owner was very friendly when he checked us in. They have 2 very loving Basset Hounds that greet you when you arrive and the fire pit in the courtyard was a great place to have a glass of wine and meet some of the other guests. We ended up talkingg to a couple from California over probably "too" many glasses ofwine for a big chunk of the evening. This would definitely be a place that we would go back to!We loved our stay at El Portal. Our pup was welcomed and given the five star treatment and of course we felt the same. The whole staff was so friendly and helpful and we loved all of their recommendations for hikes and restaurants. We stayed in the Grand Canyon room which had a wonderful soaking tub with jets that was perfect after long days of hiking Sedona. We also loved sitting by our fire reading and chatting and it made for a very cozy experience. We ended up eating at the restaurant there all three mornings for breakfast because the food was so good. I wanted to be able to package the homemade salsa and take it back to L.A with me. The location of El Portal is also very convenient and we loved being able to walk over to nearby restaurants and galleries.This place hit the spot for us. Girlfriend and I brought the dog and could not have asked for a better experience. Breakfast was amazing both the food and the atmosphere. I love how it's tucked away behind Tlaquepaque. I think the price is reasonable.Stayed here with our dog in The Hile Sept 2014. Although the place is charming and unique and great for pets, I felt it was way overpriced for what you get. We could not get our wireless access in the room. We had to go outside in the courtyard to log on. Also if you want coffee, the hotel does not provide coffee pots in the room. You have to walk over to the "Great Room" and pay 2.00 for a cup of coffee from a Keurig machine. The refrigerator in the room was very tiny. We couldn't even stand up a bottle of wine in it! The tv was so small and so far from the bed you needed a pair of binoculars to see the screen. The bedding was old and actually the whole place was old. There were cobwebs in the outside light fixtures , cracked walls, loose tiles and the place seemed dirty overall. For the prices they charge it should be impeccable. Would not recommend this place.I am writing this review a year too late. I stayed at el Portal near the end of 2013. I returned to Sedona recently and regretfully stayed with a competitor. El Portal is a real treat for the senses. The owners Connie and Steve who are frequently on site have crafted a masterpiece amongst natures' majesty in Sedona. The site exudes warmth and soul . From the rooms, to the courtyard, to the fabulous lobby , to the flavorful brunches; attention to detail and service are unmatched in Sedona. Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to a stay at el Portal! ( also look up Fran Duda at innervision for an unparalleled spiritual experience!!)
review_content_20: Breakfast served to the public. Excellent food and service in a cozy lodge dining room with large windows and garden exposure. Wild bird feeders. Pet friendly.Unless you like barking dogs, don't go here for brunch. I couldn't believe they didn't post that dogs are allowed in here for breakfast. It's not cheap, and yet you have to get your own coffee. Unbelievable! Not that good and service is mediocre. Why bother? Go to Ken's or Secret Garden Cafe just yards away. I asked why the dogs rather politely and was rudely treated. Never again.We had an absolutely lovely 2 night stay at this boutique hotel.  The staff (Terrie and owner Steve) could not have been more accommodating and helpful in every way.  The rooms are stunning, with attention to the very last detail.  The grounds and courtyard are peaceful and serene.  And we at breakfast here both days and the cook is first-rate.  We cannot wait until we have the chance to come back to Sedona and will definitely stay here again.If your willing to spend the money than you wont be disapointed! Great place to stay.. loved Boomer, the hotel greeter! It felt more like we where staying in someones home than a hotel.We will be back!We went here for breakfast because it was close to where we were staying in Sedona. I like dogs but I don't like to eat around dogs. And you will need to LOVE to eat around dogs to eat here. We sat down and after observing for a few minutes got up and left before ordering so I cant comment on the food. Looked like a neat place, but it was just lost on me.Great spot for those who appreciate a small and quiet property, attention to detail in decor and comfort, and central location. The owners have appointed the hacienda to a very high standard with each room uniquely furnished.  We liked the fire pit in the center of the courtyard with an ability to socialize and meet other guests. I agree with others that some sort of complimentary (continental style?)breakfast would be a popular add-on for the price.A home away from home! Heart-warming & charming hacienda!   We instantly fell in love with this inn. We stayed at Flat Rock Hickory for 2 nites and Arts & Crafts for 1 nite. Every room is very unique. Our puppy, Joni Mitchell, also had a fun time and enjoyed the luxury of having her own private backyard. We recently got married in San Francisco City Hall on Sept 4, 2012. Afterwards, we drove straight to Sedona for a short honeymoon.     It was hot & humid during our stay. So we didn't mind staying in our rooms, watching old movies or hanging out on their patio. Steve & Connie also have a collection of movies that guests can borrow.  Staying here made feel like we were visiting our relatives. Thank you Steve & Connie for providing us such a housewarming place to stay. We will definitely come back again, perhaps later in the year like November to see the Autumn leaves.Beautiful and quaint with excellent customer service!   Right in the heart of everything, you can chill with a glass of wine in the lodge with other guests (many with dogs) or in your spacious room with a fire and private patio.  We're thinking of spending Christmas here every year!This beautiful, secluded, and relaxing respite was absolutely perfect for a weekend get-away from the Valley during the hottest weekend of August. The owner of El Portal, Steve, was welcoming and full of information as he guided hubby, myself, and our Aussie straight to our room. Yep, it's a dog-friendly or I should say dog-welcoming place. Perfect! Cool flagstone flooring with enormous exposed woodbeams acorss the ceiling; masterfully tiled bathroom with a walk in shower and tiny jacuzzi tub and copper sinks. Super cozy, and it even had a patio. The happy hour refreshments were delicious - skip the quesadilla and focus on the olive mix and homemade salsa - wow! This intimate lodging is within walking distance of both Tlaquepaque and its beautiful shops and the touristy shops of downtown Sedona. The scenery is second to none and I couldn't be more relaxed! Thanks El Portal!Stayed there recently with my sisters and it was very nice.  I chose the Govenors Suite as there were 3 of us and it was very spacious.  Only suggestion would be to have coffee maker in the room.  We could of put on the cozy robes that were provided and gone down to the loby but was too lazy -we were on vacation.   I would stay there again.Best quasi B&B I've ever seen, very dog friendly, a little weird with the hot water.Small twelve room motel with some very involved owners and staff that make it sort of like a B&B. We stayed in The Hile room, which was beautiful and quiet. Dogs are welcomed with smiles in most of the rooms and the great room. For food, they do an honor system for coffee/beer/wine/sodas in the great room, you take something and write down your name. The do serve real breakfast, but as of at least June 2010, no longer serve lunch or dinner like the other reviewers mention In the afternoons, they have complementary finger food and some reasonably priced wines. Drinking in the courtyard is a great way to spend a couple of hours before dinner.  Also, the owners brought out a bunch of ducklings and fenced them in a small area of the grassy courtyard. Our dog was convinced they were specifically for her to watch and play with (we didn't let her play with them.) I cannot say enough good things about the service. There were a few odd things about our visit, while they serve coffee, it's only available after about 7AM. Also, it seems the hot water for showers and such is only available in the morning, no idea why.My husband and I came out here for the weekend with our two dogs. The room was adorable, the property was welcoming and cozy, we helped ourself to some of the wine and cookies in the lounge/lobby, and El Portal is located in the perfect area since it is within walking distance to shops and restaurants. Not only were our dogs treated like family (they even received a cute welcome basket with very useful goodies and treats!), but the staff accommodated our unfortunate circumstance, which we appreciated so much. We had to leave after our first night there due to a death in the family, and they did everything  possible to make our early departure seamless. Fortunately, the room was even rented out that night and we got some of our money back. Once we returned, we also realized that my husband left his sunglasses in the room in the chaos of our hasty departure. When he contacted El Portal, they immediately found them and shipped them back to us in California. I highly recommend this place to anyone visiting Sedona, and we hope to return and spend more time there in the future.If you can swallow the price tag, everything here was very nice and warm: the people, the inn, the service. Need something in the kitchen, help yourself. Our dog was truly a first class citizen. We'd gladly stay again but it may be a while before we can afford Sedona. That said, everyone should stay here once. Loved it.My boyfriend and I made a reservation here the same day we arrived. Our bungalow/ room was adorable with a nice pool and shower and great design! Was in September and super cheap ($120) for a private little building with a private patio, a tranquil courtyard and very personal and trusting care from the staff. We felt like we were in our own private resort. Would love to go back!!Just spent four nights here in Room 8, "Junipine."  This place is awesome. Only 12 rooms. The architecture, design and build quality is amazing. Steve, the owner/designer is a great guy. Breakfast is awesome, too. It's located sort of within Tlaquepaque and puts you within walking distance of many excellent galleries, shops and restaurants. This is my new, favorite Hideaway Hotel. I'll be back again and again!Room #4 Arts and Crafts is beautifully appointed, but one of the LOUDEST rooms I have ever stayed in.  You hear every footstep of the guests above you, and when they flush the toilet, the WHOOSH of the water seems like it is going to come down on your head while you are laying in your bed. This is unfortunate, because we came to Sedona for some peace and quiet, and while we were willing to pay top dollar at a highly recommended "resort", we did not get what we paid for. Very nice on the surface, but whoever constructed this place forgot to use insulation of any kind.Make sure you get a 2nd floor room if you choose to stay here.UPDATE:  I mentioned to Steve, the owner, the issues I had with room #4 and asked if we could be moved.  He was very sympathetic and apologetic and offered to move us to room 9, a second floor suite. We gratefully accepted the offer. When later in the day we went to pick up the key, we were told that #9 had been sold by another front desk person, so we would be in #8.  The room was a first floor room, not a suite, but no one was overhead. His main concern was for our comfort. We stayed in #8, the night of the incredible rain and snow storm. We had a peaceful night.  The next morning, to our surprise, our second night was comped because of the hassles. An extraordinary gesture that we did not ask for, but because of Steve's concern for our comfort, I will return and will happily spread the good word for El Portal. I do believe that you will have a genuine and personal experience should you visit. And by the way, the rooms are beautifully appointed. Thanks again to Steve and staff!The Flat Rock Hickory is the nicest room I've ever stayed in, and I've stayed at some very nice places (believe it or not).  The only thing missing is an ocean view, but hey, its Arizona.  There is a lot of attention to detail in this place, and the walls are adobe!  The only thing that's a little different is that they allow dogs, which can be good or bad depending on how you look at it.  The room was clean though, and they actually give you an empty fridge so you can put your own food or drinks in it.We stayed during a road trip with our dog and it was beautiful. Everything was perfectly done and the gardens were beautiful! The only issues we had is that breakfast is not included in the price ($200) nor is a happy hour etc. It would have been nice when you pay that kind of money to get breakfast or a glass of wine. The owners are very nice and we would definitely return.We stayed here for one night, on short notice, in September.  We endorse the more recent comment below.  Our room, #10, was as nice as any we have stayed in anywhere in the world--and we have been fortunate to have had suites in many of the finest hotels in the world.  Everything was great!!We recently stayed 2 nights at the El Portal and were very impressed.  The rooms were immaculate and designed in Southwest style that was tasteful, not kitchy.  We had the feeling we were invited into someone's home, not just staying at an inn.  Although the inn is located yards from the road, the courtyard is very quiet and peaceful.  We spent a couple of hours relaxing with our favorite beverages from the honor bar after a day of sightseeing (the drinks are reasonably priced).   We had breakfast one morning and were not disappointed.  Everything was cooked to perfection, the apple-wood smoked bacon was delicious.  If we return to Sedona, I can't see staying anywhere else.  The El Portal is perfect for a relaxing time in Sedona.
