The view from our room was quite nice, and there is a washer/dryer on the property for guests. Good place, good value.Our first trip to Sedona and this place was great!  Location was close to lots of hiking trails and the concierge was VERY helpful for a first timer.  Rooms were pretty good, nothing special but clean and beds were comfortable.  The free breakfast was perfect!  My only suggestion is to get a room in the middle building instead of one of the ones facing the street.  The road noise woke us up a few times.We will stay there again when we go back!Second time in Sedona, and second time at Sedona Real Inn. Great hotel out of the busy downtown area. Large rooms and suites at reasonable rate. Good breakfast and help desk. Plenty of restaurants and hiking trails nearby. We will stay again at this hotel on our next visit.My hubby and I stayed here for one night in March. Upon arrival, the grounds looked really nice and maintained. We weren't able to check-in but mainly b/c we arrived a little early...around 11am, so housekeepers were still working on cleaning up the rooms. It worked out fine for us since we just headed down the street to the downtown area and had some lunch @ Wildflower Bread Co. before our Pink Jeep Tour through Sedona. When we checked-in later that night, the room was ready and clean. Huge bed and more than enough room for just one night. The only qualms we had was the ridiculously loud heating vent that would kick on throughout the night, waking us up from our slumber. Other than that, quiet neighborhood and neighbors. I would probably stay there again if I came back to Sedona.Very large and comfortable rooms.  The suites have a small kitchenette (fridge, microwave, sink and coffeemaker) which can be useful, with a sitting area and gas fireplace.  Flat-screen TV in the room.  There was a double-sink area separate from the toilet/bath.  Free "continental" breakfast (except that there were eggs and sausage) and a very friendly staff.We liked the location, in West Sedona just off the main highway.  Convenience to shopping and many of the trails.  Not especially scenic but lots of Sedona (including the entire uptown drag) is not scenic per se - just surrounded by incredible scenery.Right on the main drag into Sedona, this place was reasonably priced, and easy to find.  We had a double queen suite, meaning we also had a refrigerator, which is always nice.  And the room had a fireplace that was on a switch, rather than having to light a fire.  The staff were helpful, and recommended some great places to go in town.  It was across the street from a good veg restaurant, and yet not noisey, even though it was on the highway.  There was a small walk out deck, but we didn't use it.Nice, comfortable and clean.  The rooms aren't anything special, but it was spacious and nice to have a kitchenette.  Great location, decent pool.  We booked on hotwire and were pleased with what we got.

hotel_name: Amara Resort and Spa, a Kimpton Hotel
review_content: We stayed one night and had nothing but a great experience! The location is great, the staff nice, the food good, and the room was nice and clean.They have a nightly wine "happy hour" that was a nice little extra.We had our 2 dogs with us and they were VERY dog friendly! They put dog bowls, poop bags, treats, and a dog bed in our room.We will definitely be back in the future!If I could give them a half of a star I would. This hotel lost us a checkin and never got us back. My wife and I like to stay at nice hotels and this isn't it. It felt like throwing money away. On check in the valet insisted we couldn't touch the baggage cart but then proceeded to have us unload our own luggage onto the cart (so weird!). Then he said he would meet us up in the room with the luggage. After waiting at least 15 minutes and no luggage we went back to see what happened and it was just sitting on the cart in the lobby with with three valets (including the one who said he would bring it up) just standing around talking outside- they weren't busy.They also have a resort fee of $27 a night that pays for nothing. They allow you to use the steam room at the spa but not sure that is worth the resort fee. We never used it. They also make you call for ice- a way to help their staff makes tips (probably the same issue with the luggage cart they won't let you touch). Again it just feels grubby. They need to pay their staff decently enough that the place isn't run for employee tips.The room itself showed some signs of wear. There was a glass shelf in the bathroom that was so broken and tilted it really should not have had glasses on it. I kept wondering how hard would it have been for the people that clean the room to put in a work order to have it fixed. The toilet paper holder was totally non functioning-the toilet paper wouldn't stay on-again it really showed no one cared or took "ownership".As I said we like to stay at nice hotels and are happy to pay for them. We just got back from a trip to Florida where we paid 2x as much a night for our room and it was so worth it. Find a nicer place to stay or save your money and stay at a Hampton Inn - at least you won't feel stupid throwing your money away.This place was awesome!!!I just returned home from a 2-nights stay in Sedona and totally enjoyed my time here.  The hotel/rooms were very nice but I wouldn't say overly fancy.  What they may lack (and I say "may") in over-the-top plush rooms, (tho they were very nice and comfy) they totally excel in when it comes to service!  EVERYONE was so accommodating!  We had a sign in our room that summed it up.  It's the typical sign that says "did you forget something because we've got it" and lists out all the commonly forgotten items but the sign finishes it off by saying, "...or we'll go get it"!!  That's great!  The front desk staff is very helpful in providing recommendations or printing out information on local attraction.  The morning yoga, included in the resort fee ($22 which also covers your parking), is totally a must do!  It was such a great way to start the day.  (sign up in advance!)  They have an evening "wine hour" with little nibbles and a morning coffee bar (yes, I know these are kinda common) but they also have a "make your own trail mix" bar to accommodate anyone going out for a hike.  (Which it seems to be the most popular thing to do in Sedona!)  AND, as if that isn't enough to encourage you to make your reservation right now, they have a shuttle service that will drop you off/pick you up when you are ready to head to dinner!  (Who needs Uber!?!?)   They are also dog friendly!  I'm definitely going back!Great service, outstanding location (right in the center of downtown, but tucked far away form the street so it's super quiet), perfect views of the red rocks and next to a lovely creek, coffee in the morning, free yoga, wine in the evening, free shuttle to nearby spots, and an anniversary surprise awaiting us upon check in? Of course this place is awesome!There may have been a few too many kids for my liking but, the real problem with the kids was their parents who chose not to control them.  There's nothing like 5-6 kids running around 'playing' and shrieking very loudly, building a fort out of outdoor seating cushions, and having said fort fall over and break a wine glass during the 'relaxing' wine hour overlooking the red rocks.  Again, not the hotel's fault, but, perhaps an employee who saw such shenanigans could have politely said something to the little changelings or perhaps to their parents.  That being said, I've never met a Kimpton property I didn't like and Sedona's is a great one, too! In fact, a friend of mine has chosen to stay there now based on my experiences (minus the kid part, of course!).My husband & I stayed at Amara for our baby moon. I especially appreciated the details such as hot cocoa during the complimentary wine hour for those who prefer non-alcoholic drinks. We thoroughly enjoyed the view of the red rocks as well as the fire pits outside, which staff carefully left rolled blankets for guest comfort. Salt rock restaurant is where we decided to eat almost every night because the quality of food at the hotel was superior to the touristy restaurants along the popular strip.Looking for a five-star hotel and amenities with three-star prices? Look no further. Actually, you get a three maybe four star hotel room but the hotel is upgraded to a four-star hotel due to high level of service, the majestic views and all of the amenities, including a day spa, complementary yoga classes, a beautiful pool, a nice restaurant (reasonable prices), valet parking and a convenient shuttle. The most outstanding thing about the hotel is the incredible service you are provided. Everyone in the hotel is very nice, very professional and outstandingly helpful. The one negative is that you have to take the shuttle or walk up a steep hill to get to the main strip.One surprise bonus to the hotel is the creek in the back. Its nice to see some natural waterflows in a dry desert environment.Everybody was prompt in their service, whether it was the check in, the valet or room service. See my review on the restaurant. The punchline is that it's excellent. I was a little surprised by the fact the in room movies were actual DVDs you had to get from the front desk. The selection was pretty good but it would have been nice to have a streaming service with new releases like so many other hotels. It was a little distracting with several little dogs barking. This hotel is dog friendly.I stayed here once on a work trip and absolutely LOVED it. Cushy things for sleeping, nice bathrooms, nice artwork, and Mezcal at the bar. Could a girl ask for anything more? Yes. If I were absurd, I could ask for yoga classes in the morning and a mat in my room so I didn't have to think about packing one. GUESS WHAT! They have yoga classes in the morning and a mat in your room so you don't have to think about packing one.I haven't stayed in many places in Sedona, so I can't say this place is for sure the best, but I can definitely say that I would come back and recommend this place to anyone.This is a good location, downtown Sedona with lots of local flavor in close proximity. Staff and hospitality seems to be top priority and the facility is fairly quiet. Mostly adults at this location great for couples retreat or newlyweds families with kids not so much....Great view from the court yard and nice fireplaces to sit by at night, the turf is a plus in this rocky red earth.The service we received here was fantastic from the valet guys to the front desk and everyone else we ran into.  Everyone was very friendly and helpful, anyone we came into contact with offered a greeting and offered assistance if we needed it, great staff!!  The location is nicely tucked off the main street and right by the creek, peaceful and quiet.  We had a room facing the creek and we made use of our patio in the evenings listening to the nightlife.  While we overall had a nice stay there were just a few dings that made this resort feel like it wasn't worth what we paid.  For starters we were there to celebrate my birthday and while it was never mentioned (completely ok) my boyfriend had requested a bottle of Veuve be waiting for us on arrival.  The champagne was there along with some flutes and that was all.  Really?  No ice?  Even if we had gotten in late and it had been sitting in a bucket of melted ice we would at least know they tried.  Then came the second problem, they don't have ice machines.  You need to call room service for small ziploc bags of ice.  We did and 45 minutes later I called back to check on the ice.  Another 20 minutes later we received the ice and started chilling our warm champagne.  Maybe a slight oversight but at a place like this I would expect more.  Bedding was comfortable except for the pillows, they were very thin and just plain terrible.  The room was spacious and nicely decorated.  The bathroom had a great huge spa tub, clean and well stocked.  However, the rug was frayed and old looking.  So while we had a great time around Sedona and the staff was friendly and resort clean, we were surprised by the lack of attention to detail.As for the Spa itself it was AMAZING and I think that's what really won us over.  The spa building sits right in front of the entrance to the lobby on the opposite side of the driveway.  We walked over one morning for our 10 a.m. massage appointments and the minute you walk through the door you begin to relax.  The receptionist showed me to the ladies room and explained the procedure of getting ready to wait for your masseuse.  You are given a locker to store your belongings and clothing while you're there, a robe to change into and some sandals.  There is a complete array of toiletries in case you take advantage of their showers and by complete I mean deoderant, lotions of all types for face and body, hair products for every kind of hair style, rubber bands, q tips, cotton balls, face wash, makeup remover, the list goes on.  Anyway once you have undressed you have a plush robe to head out to the waiting room.  There is a typical questionnaire you need to fill out about yourself and your body.  The room has comfortable chairs, low lighting and quiet music playing.  There is a water station with hot tea to sip while you wait.  My boyfriend and I enjoyed an extremely well done hot stone couples massage that left us feeling like jelly afterwards.  I wish I remembered our therapists names because they were so sweet.  When the massage was over they walked us over to a little inlet with two lounge chairs that could be closed off with a curtain.  They brought us a bottle of apple cider and cheers-ed us for my birthday!  I was so touched, it was the perfect little unexpected detail.  We would be back to visit the Spa in a heartbeat.Wow, what a waste of money! We were so disappointed in this hotel and the customer service. This was our first and last Kimpton. My husband and I like nice hotels and are happy to pay for them but paying for this hotel made us feel like fools. Every where you turn here it feels like they are grubbing for money. A $27 a day resort fee that pays for no services we would use. Maybe it supposed to be for the morning yoga but if I did want a yoga class it wouldn't cost $27. Checkin and the valet service was horrid and we had to actually go back to the valet to try to find our luggage after waiting 15 minutes in the room for it. The luggage was sitting in the lobby while the valets talked to each other-they weren't busy! Despite the fact they weren't bringing the luggage up to the room the valet said we could not take the cart to the room ourselves ! Help they are holding our luggage hostage! For reasons I won't go into on our last day the women at the front desk actually made a snide comment and rolled her eyes in disgust at something  my husband said. She later had the good sense to not ask us on checkout how we enjoyed our stay. I think they are trying to be a cutesy camp for adults with games, yoga, a cocoa bar etc. These are not services my husband and I need or are very impressed with -we do pretty well at planning our own trips. Again we are happy to pay for nice hotels but this place just seemed like a wanna be. We just came back from a trip to Florida where we paid 2-3x a night more for our hotel room  and it was so worth it. AND NO ONE, NO ONE should EVER make fun of a customer by making snide comments or rolling their eyes! Such behavior is immature and intended to be hurtful. Not exactly a place you want to spend your money.I saw some good reviews and my guess is that those people don't travel too much and aren't aware what they should be receiving - or maybe they are just happy to find a place that has water bowls outside for their dogs. Whatever it is, it's beyond me. Our experience was was entirely substandard and a waste of money.Awesome location right in the center of the action in uptown. The views and the infinity pool are breath taking. Great spot to check out shops and a nice launch point to explore the rocks and vortexes in the area. Valet is comp and make sure to check out the wine hour at 5 daily.We visited late December and took our pet. The room was nice a clean.  In the morning there was complimentary coffee and at night wine for social hour. We also ate at the restaurant for breakfast and it was very good.We stayed here for two nights on our way to Grand Canyon. Crazy friendly staff all around. Very clean establishment and lovely decor. Complimentary happy hour every day and build your own trail mix bar :)Love the infinity pool and view of the red rocks.Loved this place.The pool was amazing.  The staff was super accomidating.  The wine hour was fantastic, especially with the "yard" area.  At night it is a wonderful place to have cocktails by the fire.The rooms were fine.  The only problem is if you are at the end of the complex you are going to be walking forever to get anywhere, but it was fine.Everyone was great.  Definitely stay here if given the chance.I've had a soft spot for Kimpton properties for a long time, probably close to 20 years.  We were going to Sedona for part of a vacation and when I saw Kimpton had a place there, I didn't have to think about it.  But the dark side to my love of Kimpton is that they've always been amazing and I have really high expectations.If I were to compare the Amara to just any hotel, I'd be ecstatic.  And if I were to compare it to a really nice hotel like a Waldorf-Astoria, I'd still like it.  But for a Kimpton, I have to say that even though we really liked it, it was the least flawless experience I've had to date.  Maybe it's because Kimpton hotels were acquired in 2014 and changes are happening behind the scenes.  Maybe I just didn't have my usual luck.  I don't know but here are some examples:The message light on the room phone is on.  We press the message button and nothing happens.  Call the front desk to tell them we can't get our messages and they tell us we have to dial 444 for messages.  We dial 444 and the automated system says there are no voice messages but we should call the front desk for a message.  We call the front desk back and this time they're happy to give us our message.The toilet in the room is having trouble and I report it, they say they'll take care of it.  The fix lasts for 4 or 5 flushes and we have to call them back so they can try again the next morning.The artwork in the bathroom is a sign that says "Let's stay home."  What are you telling me, Amara?And after I left they charged some minibar items to my card even though I had a "Raid the minibar" credit and it should have been free.  It was fixed with a quick call.These kind of things don't normally happen at a Kimpton property.  Things just work at Kimptons and that's all there is to it.  Everybody without exception was really friendly.  Everything was very nice from the pool to the wine hour to their pet-friendly policy.  I love it all, but for problems to be where a guest can see them is just unusual.Please Kimpton, I hope you aren't starting to turn into just another hotel chain.Okay, more about the Amara.  The views are as amazing as anywhere in Sedona and access to the creek is a real plus.  But the driveway is a minus.  It's steep, it's curvy, it's dark at night.  And in parts, pedestrians have to share the narrow road with people who don't know where they're going.  The hotel's shuttle give you a lift up to the street if you want and then come get you if you need them to.  At night, take them up on this.Although much of the review deals with small problems, I was really happy with our stay at the Amara.  Nothing significant went wrong and that's something I've always been able to count on.  Seriously, stay here.  You'll be pampered, you'll have a terrific time, and you'll probably get to meet a few friendly dogs in the lobby as well!A surprise on many fronts. Following a business trip to Phoenix, my husband surprised me with a trip to Sedona. He then surprised me by making hotel arrangements. I was enthralled with his choice. The room was clean and spacious. The maid actually left us a note to thank us for the tip we left. We had two meals at the hotel:  who knew that deviled eggs with maple syrup and a tart onion marmalade would work so well. The staff chose a delightful tequila for my husband and I sipped a hot tottie. We spent a day hiking (we got lost or it would have been shorter.). Returned to hotel for a much anticipated couples massage. Our stay was too short. Weather became a factor, so we reluctantly left early (us SoCal folks can really wuss out.).   My husband promised to return to Sedona in the spring and there will be no guessing where we will stay. Amara has it all: great location, beautiful accommodations, great food and wonderful spa. See you in April!PS. Staff is also top notch!This place is a dump! Booked a four night stay here and immediately regretted it. The place looks and feels like a dirty old motel with modern furniture. And guess what?! That's EXACTLY what it is! It's outdated, cramped and GHETTO. When Kimpton bought this old crappy hotel two years ago they only spent 1M to revamp it. For those of you who have never renovated a house, 1M IS NOT REAL MONEY. And this isn't just a house - this is an entire resort. From the crappy 80's-style original metal railings to the motel balconies and the DISGUSTING  old mattresses, this place is a crap hole! We tried switching to the Enchanted or the L'Auberge but since it's high season they were sold out. Stay away from this place!! Yuck!!The 2 stars is ONLY for the staff! The guys at valet and the shuttle are the BEST!!!!!This hotel is gorgeous! The pool area is relaxing and the view is amazing. We loved the hotel staff. The font desk ladies were helpful and personable. The food was delicious and we had a great server. I sing understand why people would give a bad review.Could not have asked for a better spot! Right by the creek, amazing vista of the red rocks. Rooms are pristine, hotel grounds are immaculate! The little things this hotel offers go a long ways: smores kit by the fire, wine-hour in lobby, make your own trail mix. All sort of little amenities and the staff is very attentive and kind.Stayed three nights for a very special long weekend.  Be careful on the room they choose for you.  Opened our drapes and viewed a ladder against a fence and what looked to be a construction site behind the fence.  Notice their website only shows the beautiful view!  There were three of us in the room and we had to request wash cloths and towels twice.  Hair dryers are very cheap and overheat quickly so we had to request more since there was only one hair dryer in the room.  Too much money for a view of a ladder and construction area.  To arrive at our room, we had to enter and exit three buildings.  It is very dark between the buildings at night.  Of course we were assigned a room as far from the front entry as you could possibly be.  Not impressed with this hotel.
review_content_20: Sedona was great, but it was really staying at the Amara that was the icing on the cake. First off, the place itself is cozy, yet with an eclectic/upscale vibe that makes you feel somewhere special. To elaborate: there was a mixture of bright colors to accent features, yet still wooden aspects as well. I guess you could call it "hipster" for lack of a better term. The infinity pool reflects one of the impressive rock formations in the area, and they have a restaurant that overlooks the pool and grass area where people can enjoy a drink and relax. One other thing: they are right on the creek and have a nice walkway down to this so you can enjoy a stroll on the creek. The service was spectacular as well. The valet gentlemen there are the highlight though! There is free valet which is a huge benefit because you are able to walk to a lot of the shops and restaurants in the area. The valet guys though are extremely personable and literally run to your car to guarantee efficiency in timing.  One of the maids went out of her way to wish us a happy day, and the concierge upon arrival was really nice as well. For me it is also the little things that make a place great and unique: there was a water bowl outside welcoming the dogs that were guests at the hotel as well, you have free access to yoga classes and a sauna that are offered by the spa, there is a complementary wine hour and they have really great quality shampoo/conditioners. One con though!! There were no coffee makers in the room. They did have complementary coffee until 10 in the lobby, but I am someone that appreciates waking up in your robe and having a cup of coffee without going to fetch it. And the room service coffee is $4 a cup! Overall I really loved this place and know that there will not be another place in Sedona that I will venture to.Amazing property and team. Katie B was our host for Christmas vacation 2016. She and her team were simply outstanding. The kids were given special attention and our whole family of 10 loved the experience. Thank you Katie and team Amara!!!With a heavy heart I can only give three stars. Cheers to the location in town and great views. And the staff for the most part were nice. I really loved the infinity pool (albeit small) and the game area, in all its AstroTurf glory. In response to the other reviewers comment on the restaurant hours, everything in Sedona seems to close at 9, nor does anything open particularly early, either. It's a weird town that way. I just don't see this as a 4-star hotel--my room just seemed grimy in a way paint can't just cover, I could barely get into my bathroom because the door kept sticking, there were makeup soaked fingerprints all over the bathroom that weren't my shade, the bath products were weak, the pillows lumpy...  And the workout room is a dungeon.  Short of the long: the not-negligible room prices are for location, not necessarily quality. Which is kinda true throughout all of Sedona, in retrospect. So just... Be aware.   I'm thinking the 5-star ratings may be from people who don't travel much.Great location! Hotel rooms are a bit dated, but they make up for it with service and lobby.  Love the complimentary coffee bar every morning, and wine in the evening.  Attached restaurant has great food and drinks.  Unfortunately, there were some storms that rolled in, so we were unable to enjoy the beautiful pool. We did, however, get a chance to enjoy the fire pit outside with a glass of wine.Customer service is amazing-- valet was on point every time (we retrieved our car at least 7 times) and front desk was very accommodating.  THANK you to the front desk for acknowledging our anniversary and sending us a special treat to our rooms!My husband and I specifically booked a room at the Amara because we love Kimpton properties and try to stay in them every time we travel.  This property does not live up to the experience we have come to expect.  The property itself is not as visually appealing as others.  When we asked the front desk staff where we could find a store with greeting cards, he seemed to be unfamiliar with the area and didn't offer much help.  Even worse, we had specifically told the hotel prior to our arrival that we had just gotten married on July 18 and that this was the first stop on our honeymoon.  There was no mention of this when we checked in, there was no note or anything in the room to mark the occasion.  When we have stayed at Kimpton hotels for special occasions in the past, the hotel always goes out of their way to celebrate it.  At the Canary in Santa Barbara, they provided a bottle of champagne and a card for my husband's (then fiance) birthday.  At the Amara?  Nothing.On top of all that, we realized less than an hour after we left that we had forgotten three garments in the closet.  When we called back, the staff was really not helpful in terms of trying to address it.  They transferred me to housekeeping, where I just kept getting bounced from voicemail to voicemail.  I called the hotel again and had to give my credit card information for the shipping and was promised a call back.  No call back.  We called twice more to confirm that they had found my garments and then were promised a call with a tracking number.  Still waiting on that call.  The customer service here is NOT what we expect from Kimpton.  My husband and I will continue to stay at Kimpton properties elsewhere but would not waste our money at Amara. I recommend you don't waste yours there either!Lack of basic amenities was shocking. Asked for ice bucket and got delivered 2 ziplock full of ice. Bizarre.Restaurant bar & room service all end at 9pm.No real service at the pool.Glasses for toothbrushes are placed above the toilet bowl. Gross. Low quality of bedding and furniture doesn't match the price at $400/ night. Everything felt so cheap and corners cut. Overpriced and feel ripped off. For $400 / night?! Albanian bartender was very nice and made nice cocktails.View of the parking lot for $300 a night? Underwhelmed to say the least. The place is filthy. I cancelled my second night reservation and fortunately got a refund. I was surprised that the hotel clerk didn't ask me for feedback. The best part of the stay were the Valets who offered me ice water on my way out.Amara Resort and Spa was such a beautiful and relaxing place to stay, my boyfriend and I couldn't have asked for more from the resort during our 5 day stay.  It felt like a five star hotel, but without the pretentious attitude.  Wine hour was definitely a fun time, and we loved that you can either relax inside or outside in the grass or pool area.  David was working the wine hour one of the nights and really made an effort to get to know my boyfriend and I. I also want to mention the wonderful people working at the spa.  Jacy and Megan (I believe that was her name) were so great and helped us both book our appointments for massages, and were so friendly and welcoming.  They knew it was my boyfriend's birthday, so they sent him off with an adorable personalized bday card, face cream samples and some epsom salt to use at a later time after his massage. The spa was so clean and peaceful, we were very impressed with it all.  We were also very pleased with our massages, as they were just what we needed. :)Thank you to everyone for the wonderful service, including all of those we didn't mention, since everyone was so great.  We honestly can't wait to return!!This place is absolutely wonderful. The resort grounds are beautiful and the atmosphere is relaxing and serene. Everyone at the hotel is friendly, helpful and responsive. Special shout out to Dustin (sp?) the bartender at Saltrock (restaurant inside resort). He was friendly, nice and a great bartender! We truly enjoyed sitting and chatting with him and other hotel guests. Nathan and Chelsey at the front desk were also wonderful and helpful! The $22/day resort fee is nothing considering the amenities this place provides, i.e yoga class, complimentary wine hour from 5-6 (you can sit inside or outside by the fire pits and watch the sun set) and the hot chocolate and coffee bar, the coffee is amazing! The shuttle the resort offers is extremely convenient and quick. They also have a list of things they provide free of charge that people frequently forget, i.e. phone charger, toiletries, razors, etc.! Finally, we were here for our anniversary and the resort gave us a special gift and a handwritten card. This place is truly a wonderful get away and we had a fabulous experience.I stayed for only one night but had a great experience. The hotel is built right on the river and still has great views of the canyons and bluffs.  They also have pretty much any amenity you could ask for: free yoga in the morning, spa, infinity pool, giant Jenga and lawn games, fire pits, free wine happy hour and more. The staff is friendly and the rooms are spacious and very nice. The hotel is also near a shopping strip so you can check out shops and restaurants.The drive into Sedona though the 89A canyon is also breathtaking.This hotel just needs a good, long combat tour in Vietnam.I enjoyed my stay here, though it wouldn't necessarily have been my first choice. My wife booked the place, and if you are into the crunchy, hippie, holistic spa experience, you will absolutely love it. I was just pleased that the rooms were clean, they had a nice pool and smoked bacon at breakfast that was so damned good I needed a 3 hour, Australian-imported eucalyptus-infused hot quartz river rock glute massage to calm down. The location can't be beat either, as it is centrally located among many of the shops and restaurants, though set back just enough to remain a peaceful retreat. Check out the fire pits with complimentary blankets after the sun goes down- I believe you'll find the experience more relaxing than an Acai and wheatgrass upside-down high colonic administered by a Swedish fitness model wearing a cucumber and bitter melon mud mask.This is a lovely hotel with a lovely situation and some great service, the valets and some of the front desk are wonderful. The pool is lovely but shallow throughout and smaller.  The grounds and situation are some of the best around and it backs up to a lovely walk along the river.  They serve wine and a few snacks in the evening which is a nice touch.  This alone might be worth it for you but the rest of the hotel did not live up to my expectations at the price point.  For the price, which is about 20-40% more than I've paid for four and five star resorts in Hawaii and Europe, it just doesn't compare all that favorably.  At $200 a night I'd be all about it, but if I compare it to say, the Hapuna Beach Prince or the Mauna Kea in Hawaii, it doesn't stand up and I've stayed both places for less than I paid here.  Of course, local economy always factors in but I don't think one can argue that Hawaii's local economy is more forgiving than Sedona's.  How did it not stand up? A) The bathrooms are tiny and not luxuriously appointed.  There is one small sink on a stand - no vanity or space for toiletries. There is a temporary moveable cart across from the toilet. Even the toilet paper is awkwardly positioned.  Other reviews mentioned the toiletries; they were not premium - fine but not premium. I've had kiehls toiletries in other 4-5 star hotels - this wasn't that quality.  Moreover a bag of unopened sample size premium toiletries that I brought with me was thrown away on the second day of my stay and only the ziploc bag was replaced (after my second phone call to the front desk). B) The rooms are not large. The size alone is not such a problem but in the double rooms the bases of the beds stick out beyond the mattresses and consistently catch the shins of the taller among us as there isn't a whole lot of room to navigate around them.  I have black and blue shins - really.  C) Entertainment systems - no premium channels or guide that I could find and no speakers or stereo for plugin to smart phone.  I missed my music. Wi-fi requires payment - your money or all your information - you pick and you'll have to sign in every time. D) Some rude staff.  Was admonished by a bar-tender for slopping a bit of coffee on the bar after putting some ice in my coffee. One woman followed me in to the lobby restroom just after this and sort of scared me with her effusive inquiries about my stay but that might just be me being strange.  E) For a hotel that prides itself on being a resort and spa, I expect good workout facilities.  Workout room was sub-par; windowless and grey with only one funky looking elliptical machine (there were other machines, just one elliptical).  Really, the windowless thing was the biggest problem. F) This is a bit nit-picky but the patios opening to the pool are filled with sharp little rocks so if you intend to barefoot it from your room to the pool, you'll have a few moments of masochism. In the end, I don't regret staying here and I won't completely rule out a return but I was left feeling uncomfortable with the value for the reasons outlined above.I absolutely love Kimpton Hotels and when I saw they had a property in Sedona, I jumped at the chance to stay here.  I paid extra to get a room overlooking Oak Creek Canyon and I was not disappointed.  The room was gorgeous and complete with two patios and a Jacuzzi tub that looked out onto Oak Creek and red cliffs behind it.  The grounds were very nice, too.  I went for Valentine's Day weekend and the pool was heated so my little Valentines spent a few hours swimming while I relaxed one of the comfy cabana beds.  When the wine hour started, they had a choice between wine and hotty toddies, I chose wine and went back to the pool.  When I went back for seconds the person serving wine accused me of breaking the glass because I was sitting in the pool area, I hadn't noticed but the glass had a crack.  I was taken back that I was being accused of breaking the glass instead of receiving an apology for being served wine in a broken glass.  When we arrived back in our room we noticed some ants had gathered at the sink to lick our toothpaste. On our way to go for a walk, I notified a staff member and it was never addressed again.  Throughout our stay we saw more ants in the sitting room and again in the shower.  Since no one was bitten, I just let it go.  The food from the hotel restaurant was delicious.  The staff was really laid back but accommodating in their own way.  I will definitely be back, ants and all.I'm glad this was only my birthday and not a really special occasion. We're not waiting 10-15min upon arrival to get our bags to room, I may be disabled, but I can take the cart to our room. While getting there someone from accounting was insisting that he get someone to help... Here's a thought, have people from accounting plus-up the front door on a Friday evening so as not to give a bad 1st impression.In room, (with parking lot views full of Toyota Prius) the staff is still delivering items that should be there upon check in, like robes, towels, etc There is not a coffee pot like in every other hotel room in the 1st world, no one gets to call... Wait... And then call back to find out what's taking so long. I'm from Seattle, we don't wait for coffee!Sure it looks nice, it's in Sedona, but if the service doesn't support your ambience then you're an overpriced place to avoid. (like having a "W" Hotel in Apache Junction) Now we will return to Chandler, AZ. We'll get with our bike & running friends and we will tell them how my birthday was. Save the place we stayed. On that note, your website is impressive!We won't be investigating any other Kimpton locations.My husband and I went to Sedona overnight and we stayed at the Amara.  We had a wonderful room that overlooked Oak Creek.  Our room was amazing - two bathrooms (one was a powder room), the other had an awesome Jacuzzi tub, a living room area, large bedroom with a king-sized bed, snacks, water, drinks, an in-room coffee maker, and three (yes, 3) balconies.  They have a happy hour (complimentary wine) -- we took ours out to the outdoor seating area which looks out towards the mountains. Even though it's June, it had just rained and was cooling off so the fire pits were going.  It was so pleasant to sit around the fire pit, talk and enjoy a glass of wine.  Everyone was super friendly and helpful. Service was exceptional. We'll definitely go back!We visited Sedona in March of this year and only ended up booking at the Amara because most other places were sold out and I am so glad it happened this way! Everyone who helped us that trip was so incredible, so naturally, when we got 5 days to come back to Sedona, this time Amara was our first choice! Each night, their complimentary wine hour begins at 5 p.m. and ends at 6 p.m. This is a great time to enjoy a few glasses of wine, meet a few new folks, play a game of scrabble or tic-tac-toe in the comfortable lobby. Other options include enjoying the breathtaking red rock views outside in the courtyard, or sitting by the fire outside the SaltRock restaurant. They have huge "connect 4" style games in the courtyard, and also a large beanbag game. It is perfect to keep you busy and engaged! We had a great time playing these games. Each night, we met new folks and now have new friends! Each staff member who served the wine each night was always incredibly friendly and open and full of great ideas to share! The gentleman who set up the wine hour in March was the same gentleman who was setting up and breaking down the wine hour this time also, and he is just fantastic! He is an incredible employee, always doing whatever it takes to make the guests feel welcome and happy! We enjoyed the complimentary yoga classes with Cathleen both stays! We were so happy to know she was still here when we returned last week! She is truly a wonderful yoga instructor and really inspires you to want to live life more peacefully! Her optimism and happiness is contagious and you just leave class feeling incredibly grateful and inspired.... They offer a complimentary shuttle to anywhere within a mile of the hotel. We didn't know this until half way through our stay this time. This is an awesome option and would highly recommend it as a means for sober dinner transportation after the wine hour! We made dinner reservations for Mariposa and got a ride there (and back) from Amara's free shuttle service! (They give you a business card to call when you're ready to be picked up and were there in less than 10 minutes). Awesome service and excellent drivers!!! The men running the valet (and holding the doors) were all, always fantastic! Always prompt and friendly service!  Love them and their stories about how they ended up in Sedona and at the Amara. The hotel smells great! Only wish I knew what the scent was, because I so want it in our home!  They always have fruit-infused ice water in the lobby, and depending on the time of day, either coffees/teas, or build-your-own trail mix.... Yum! The entire hotel is pet-friendly, no breed or weight restrictions. Have yet to see any issue with this. All dogs have been great, no animal waste anywhere, no loud barking, no pet smells lingering.... However they do it, it works! They even have dog bowls, food and beds for free if you decide to bring your little buddies along. Out behind the hotel, there is a peaceful little creek. If you walk out to that creek and head right, you will walk over to L'Auberge de Sedona on your own little dirt path and that restaurant has awesome creek-side dining. Sometimes, the terrace is closed but even the views from inside were fantastic. Service and food there were both great as well. We spent about an hour or so, watching 4 river otters swim and fish and play. There are comfortable chairs and bench swings to enjoy the sounds of the rushing water and happy ducks. It is really its own little hidden treasure out back. There are also dvd rentals available, as well as awesome spa amenities and a fitness center, but we didn't take advantage of these this trip. I highly recommend the courtyard or creek view rooms. We loved having first floor, courtyard, because we could walk off patio to pool, courtyard, restaurant, creek.... It was another fantastic time! Would absolutely recommend this to ANYONE heading to Sedona, as it is completely worth the money!We stayed here for our wedding and I wouldn't have changed a thing. The next time we are in Sedona, The Amara is a MUST! They made sure every detail of our stay was perfect. They have impeccable customer service and their restaurant is phenomenal! We can't wait to go back and visitThe Amara in Sedona is the greatest place in the world. It is my version of Heaven. My husband and I were married at the creek behind the hotel three years ago, and continue to come back several times a year. I cannot say enough great things about this hotel. They know how to do it. Below are a few of the highlights: 1) views: The hotel has the most incredible views of Sedona. I have stayed in several rooms in the hotel and everyone is top notch with a great view. 2) The staff: Everyone there is so awesome, helpful and kind-Best customer service!!!3)The food: Dang! Just Amazing food!4) The pool! This is the only hotel that knows how to do the pool right! They make it so relaxing and amazing! Its so amazing because they don't have a dj and base music playing like all the other hotel pools, they ensure the tranquility of Sedona. The most relaxing place in the world. I highly recommend staying at this hotel. It is the only hotel that we stay at, and our favorite hotel to vacation of any place that we vacation!The Location: Keep your GPS on to find this place. The "street" that it is on looks like a small driveway from the road, and their sign by the road is quite small. We would have passed it if we didn't have the GPS on. You drive down this long, windy drive to the hotel, which has a great view of some of the red rocks for which Sedona is famous. It's like a secret. I like the way it is nestled away.The Hotel: I wouldn't really call this a resort, but the "resort fee" does include valet parking, which is well worth the price ($22/day I think). The set-up is a little awkward (you can only get upstairs using the stairs or elevator at one end, and not at the other; the hallways are broken up so that you have to open doors repeatedly to get down the hall - going outside and then back in), but all the rooms are on one side or another of the inner courtyard, which has large cozy chairs, fire pits, the pool and the hot tub and an incredible view. It's a pet-friendly hotel, so you'll get to see and meet a bunch of dogs (which is great for dog-lovers like myself). It's a Kimpton, so you get the Kimpton perks like a daily wine hour and free wifi.The Room: The room was big and on the ground floor facing the pool and the hot tub, which was tremendously convenient when we wanted to use those facilities. The closet was also very big. There were plenty of windows, including three cute little square ones, and the large patio door. The decor was very cute. The beds were comfortable, too. The room came with two robes, which came in handy when we wanted to go to the pool.There were a few details that were overlooked, though. There were not enough hooks in the bathroom, and there was no towel bar for a hand towel by the sink. We improvised, but they could fix this easily. The shower/tub faucet is strange and not intuitive. I had to fiddle with it for a few minutes to figure out how it worked (It turns one way for the tub, the other way for the shower, and an inner knob controls the temperature of the water). Also, the closet doors were awkward & the lighting switch for the closet was next to the mini-bar. It just didn't make sense. Also, they only had one yoga mat and one umbrella in the room. You can get extra ones by calling the front desk. Also, we were on the ground floor, and our upstairs neighbors were running around at 4am the first night of our stay. They were maddeningly loud. I wish the hotel would advise guests about quiet hours and having guests below them.The Restaurant/Bar: Saltrock. Their menu is quite limited, and I don't think they offer breakfast except for in-room dining. It says their focus is "Craft Margaritas," but they only had a handful of margaritas on the menu. El Passion was really great. Spicy & sweet. We ordered the guacamole even though it is, by far, the most expensive guacamole I've ever ordered. It was this strange "make your own" guac concept that was interesting (you add tomatoes/jalapenos/cilantro/mango) to your own taste to some avocado pulp. It needed onions. I would have preferred some really good guacamole without the gimmick.The Service: It was clear that they set our room up for us before we got there. They stocked the place with complimentary vegan, gluten-free treats, including cookies, rice chips and hummus. They left me a postcard welcoming me and explaining all of the goodies they left for me. Talk about service! We had some lighting issues, which were promptly fixed after we reported them. The bellmen were really nice, friendly and helpful, and always offered restaurant suggestions and tips. Basically everyone we met there (with rare exception) was incredibly nice and helpful. They put our stay over the top. The people really made the difference.The Spa: As a guest of the hotel, you can use the facilities at the spa, including the steam rooms (separated by gender), the relaxation lounge, and you can take their 8:30am yoga class, which is limited to 9 participants. You can sign up in advance (we signed up 2 days in advance), or just show up around 8:15am and wait to see if there are any no-shows. The Spa services are a little pricey, but not tremendously out of the ordinary. They have a long menu of services that can meet any of your needs. I got a facial for the first time, and my face is still glowing days later. Their robes are deliciously cozy, and they have basically every personal care product you would need.The most annoying thing was that their standard hair dryers (in the hotel rooms and in the spa) are so cheap. I should have asked them for a "High Powered Hair Dryer." I didn't even notice it on the list of complimentary items. I'm not sure why their standard hair dryers are so cheap, as the other Kimptons I've been to offer much better hair dryers. It took forever to dry my hair.Join Karma Rewards BEFORE you book your room and look for room specials. I wound up getting a cheaper rate that included two free hot toddies just by searching their website.Beautiful property in a beautiful setting. The room was very comfortable and clean overlooking the pool and red rocks. Breakfast, Dinner and wine hour were all excellent. Staff was very helpful with hiking information and directions when needed. My new go to hotel in Sedona.
review_content_40: This place is nestled from the main street. It's a little tricky finding it so make sure you watch your gps when finding the road. The place is cute. The decor lives up to the Kimpton standards, but there were things here and there that could be improved upon. The best part of this place was the service and staff. Everyone was very friendly and accomodating, from check-in to check-out. The room was ok. It was a little smaller than expected. The amenities were ok, they use Bigelow. The hair dryer was terrible (yes, this matters, at least to me). One thing that was bad was the temperature of the water. It never got hot enough even though it was turned to the hottest setting. The hotel property was nice. They had outdoor and indoor games available for the guests. They served coffee and tea in the morning and a happy hour (red/white wine and snacks) around 5. They also knew it was my birthday and left a bottle of champagne (with my name on it) waiting for us. I was really impressed by that. They also have the spa amenities available at no cost. They definitely have quite a few quirks compared to other places. One of my favorite things were the fire pits and seats with blankets (at night) available for the guests. I would recommend this property if people are looking for a place to stay in Sedona.This place is awful! First off the wait for dinner was 39 min when plenty of tables were open. They said only 2 servers where on but there were 4. The dinner was disgusting I got a pork belly dish and it was nachos with crap in it. The manager was a old 50 year old drunk with a side braid and couldn't tell one thing from the next. Plus our room smells like a wet dog. Awesome. Not worth the money.The sweets are 5 star however I had to be down graded the second night. The normal room bathroom was tiny and the bathtub had a bunch of dings in it. If you don't have a coffee maker in the room offer coffee all day. Check in wasn't until four which kind of sucks and the restaurants food was just mediocre (they couldn't even cook a medium rare steak). The good, the grounds are gorgeous and the service is amazing. Everyone was outstanding. The rooms minus the bathroom were updated and clean. Overall for the price just average, hence the 3 stars. One last item, if you are paying a resort fee the valet should not accept a tip, probably my fault for offering but something that should be addressed.Not only is this a great resort but their staff is phenomenal. My sister and I stayed here one night and wished we would have stayed longer. We took advantage of their free happy hour from 5-6 and their free shuttle service to and from the hotel to one of the restaurants downtown. Such a lovely service and the staff were so friendly and cheerful. It's so nice to experience this kind of customer service and we really appreciated the way we were taken care of. Beautiful grounds, cozy and quaint rooms, and lovely views. I would recommend this place to anyone staying in Sedona.This is by far my favorite place to stay in Sedona. These beds should be standard in all hotels. Quiet, clean, right on the creek. I love being able to walk right up to the center of town. If your legs can't handle the hike the valet will drop you off or drive you to wherever you need to go. They already had my business before we found out they are a dog friendly hotel at no charge. Can't wait to visit again.It was my first time in Sedona and I loved it. In spite of the weather being colder/rainier than one would expect in Arizona, it was a great time. Chill vibe without compromising amenities. Overall really enjoyed the experience at Amara. Pros:- clean and good sized rooms- good amenities - coffee hour in the lobby in the morning- wine hour in the lobby in the evening- nice spa with good services- super friendly valets- pet friendly (I don't have a dog but love them and figured it was a helpful thing to point out!)- nice hot tub and infinity pool with a gorgeous viewCons:- concierges were not super knowledgeable and/or they simply weren't into helping out of towners. They seemed to expect us to know where we wanted to go vs. looking to then for recommendations. For instance: we asked about a hiking trail that would be fun but not super challenging for newbies and the response was "ok which one?"- service was a little awkward in the restaurant like they were trying to rush us out even though there were plenty of open tables. Not exactly rude maybe just confusedWe were only here for one night but thoroughly enjoyed our stay. There are many nice hotels in Sedona, I'm not sure why my hubby picked this one but I'm glad he did. The location is great- right in the middle of uptown. It's easy to miss the entrance but just drive slow and keep your eyes out for the Amara sign. The decor is modern, our room was nice, no frills but large and clean. We loved the gorgeous views of the red rocks from the restaurant and the pools. The whole place felt like an oasis. We also loved the coffee and hot chocolate bar in the morning, wine hour, and I LOVED the yoga class at the spa on Sunday mornings.First off, Sedona is an amazing destination. For the entire weekend I was there, I could only say, "Wow." The people in the town, locals and tourists are so amazingly polite and hospitable. Now onto the resort. I booked the Amara after reading reviews on Hotels.com and selecting it based upon the amenities, the view and the price. The purpose of the trip was to celebrate my anniversary with my girlfriend and the Amara did not disappoint.When booking, I had to call the hotel because I had a difficult time understand the room selections (you want to overlook the pool/courtyard). They were amazingly pleasant on the phone and supremely helpful. Right away, I had a great experience and I still had weeks to go before I stayed there.Some people say it's tough to find, but if you do your diligence and map it out, understand how the town works, it's not that tough to find. The road off of 89A is marked with their hotel sign and the road is even named Amara Road. We were greeted by the valet who was one of the better valets I've had experiences with, his name was Orlando and he was helpful the entire weekend. Valet is included in the resort fee, but don't forget to tip every time you want your car, it's just polite. We entered the resort to check in and the front desk staff knew enough to wish us a Happy Anniversary (because I mentioned it in the comments when booking). It was a great way to kick off the weekend. The resort is smaller than you think, but that's not a bad thing at all. You get to know the staff pretty quickly and you get to meet others who are staying there as well (all were very nice and open to talking). The heated pool is a little colder than you think, but the hot tub makes up for it.Entering the room, we were greeted with a bottle of wine and chocolate-covered strawberries. I didn't ask for those, they were a present from the resort and they were very welcome. Also, we had a handwritten note wishing us a happy anniversary. You don't find things like that anymore.The room walls are a bit thin and proximity to the courtyard is pretty close, but since you go out hiking all the time and out for dinner, you don't really notice.The view is spectacular as is the walk down by the creek. Check out the restaurant for brunch, but I recommend venturing out for dinner. Speaking of which, one thing to keep in mind about Sedona, everything closes in that town around 9pm, including nightlife - so plan accordingly.We will definitely be back and I will recommend this place to all my friends!I loved this hotel. Cant wait to go back to Sedona and stay here again.1. Great location - walking from the main street with restaurants2. Great service - there is a shuttle that will take you around a 1 mile radius and valet is included in the resort fee3. Welcome dogs happily! There are rooms that go right into the grass area to take them out potty (super plus!!!!)4. The room and resort was very nice and modern.I LOVE the setting, with the creek on the other side of the infinity pool. That was the highlight by far. Room was nice, grounds were cool looking and framed the beautiful redrocks quite nicely. Oh, and the valet guys...awesome. They hustle with a smile. Can't say enough about them, and I think they all need a raise. So courteous and helpful. A couple things I would change 1) The woman who I first spoke with at the front desk after our 8 hour drive should not be there. I don't know her name, she is young and seemed like it was her first day everyday. It's not just me, over the course of our stay I witnessed and overheard other guests have similar sentiments. She needs to not be in the front, probably a very nice girl, just needs to have a different role. 2) Since you are so far away, you feel a bit trapped with the food situation. There is no continental breakfast or snacks or anything, just very basic coffee early AM and wine before dinner. There is room service from SaltRock, which is very good, just expensive. I wish there was a continental breakfast or something in the morning. 3)Customer service is a bit off here. I was so excited one night they advertised smores. Cheesy I know, but fun nonetheless. When I arrived, the woman running the Smores said, oh we're out of chocolate. I was disappointed, and asked if there was any chocolate in the kitchen or anything. She said no, and then laughed and just said, the kids took all of it. Then, said, well, now i know for next time to buy more chocolate. Ummm, then she walked away. Look, I didn't NEED the chocolate, but customer service 101 would suggest that she apologize and then offer something, a voucher, another dessert, or something. It's not like I'm staying at the Motel 8.This really might be my favorite hotel of all time.My boyfriend and I were on a group vacay with my two best friends and we got two rooms here for a slightly reduced rate. We went based on reviews and a friend of a friend's recommendation, and we felt like we struck gold.To be clear, this is pricier than a Hilton or Marriot, but the extra touches were so lovely and the time we spent there was so relaxing, I don't regret a penny.As we arrived, we were told valet was included in our stay - why thank you! Each of our couples was checked in and offered free yoga, and immediate openings for spa appointments. We were oriented to lovely extras such as coffee hour in the morning, wine hour in the evening, not only a great pool and hot tub but cabanas on the pool patio, and a shuttle up the hill and "within a mile" around town. We found our rooms to be tremendously lovely and plush. Both of our rooms had private balconies with seating, the washroom was phenomenally well appointed, and the room had a tranquil feeling. And our bed was magnificent! Our room, in particular, was so big that the four of us took to gathering in it, playing cards, making drinks, and relaxing.On our second day we realized that there was some kind of workshop taking place in the meeting room just a couple of doors down the hall from us. What's interesting about this is that we found out this was happening when we left our room and found a throng of people in the hall - from inside the room we couldn't hear it at all! That's some awesome soundproofing.We chose never to use the shuttle as walking up the hill and around town was part of our evening routine. (This hotel is lovely inside and out, and because it's down the hill, you feel you're far away from town, but in actuality it's 3 minute trek up the hill to go get coffee, food, or to just walk and window shop!) However, valet was always prompt and helpful (and we were happy to tip them for it). I also had a wonderful experience when I found that the second floor ice machine wasn't working (sounds weird I know) - I ran into hotel staff on my walk back from the defunct ice machine, told them, and he said "just give me your room number and I'd be happy to send up two ice buckets!" That's quality service right there.Checkout is luxuriously late, and they were FAST. I was a bit nervous about having pre-paid and then owing "resort fees" but it was really only $20 a day - I say that's money well spent for the level of service we got all over the hotel. I'd go back in a heartbeat.Nice Sedona resort. Very warm and service oriented with fresh squeezed juices. Very inviting and welcoming. The rooms are not huge but well architected with interesting fixtures and decor.Loved this place! Close to shops in Sedona, pretty view, fun games outsides such as corn hole, giant connect 4 & jenga, lemon infused water for guests that was perfect for the heat, and cute trail mix bar and hot cocoa bar. I loved the details. I recommend this hotel if you are visiting Sedona.Great Hotel , solid service, new rooms. Centrally located - but in the valley not the best view. Overall a solid experience.We stayed at the Amara for one night with our dog, Annie. The hotel is actually fairly small when you get inside. The courtyard area at the center of the building is very nice. Although pretty, be warned that the "red rock view" is just the center courtyard. The bathroom was ok, but the shower had a strange shower control that we figured out by accident. Everyone was very friendly to our dog which was very nice. There's not a lot of areas for your pet to relieve themselves. The hotel is segregated into sections, so walking through 4-5 sets of doors to get to our section was a bit annoying with a pet in tow. Everything closes at 9pm and the bar at 10pm, which was disappointing to find out on a Friday night when we got in at 8:30pm. The staff was nice to you, but not really personable. They felt cold and we were ignored at the restaurant more than once. For the price, I feel like we had been a bit jipped.I mainly chose Amara because of their pet policy, but I'm glad I went regardless of pet or not. First the rooms are huge and I felt that the fair is very reasonable.The stay at Amara was a breeze and I would definitely go back as it was so nice to be able to walk through downtown Sedona.Pros:-Free valet-Very accommodating to pets -Coffee in the lobby in the morning, and wine in the afternoon! -Variety of spa services even in room massages-Ideal location in downtown Sedona-Great pool outside and fire pits to snuggle close to.Cons:-As others have mentioned, you have to pay for wifi-There is a $20 fee per day, I can see why some wouldn't like it, but I didn't mindOverall I very much enjoyed Amara. Their restaurant near the lobby was okay and they have live music at night which is pretty nice.Centrally located but set back from the main road. "Downtown" sedona is easily accessible by walking however the hotel offers a free shuttle to/from locations within a 1 mile radius which we used extensively. Awesome views in a serene setting, excellent service and a restaurant that can get very crowded on weekends. The rooms are pretty much as shown in the pictures - clean and comfortable. I'd return.We absolutely loved our stay at Amara. Located right in the heart of Sedona, this resort was a great find. Our favorite aspects were the spacious rooms, accommodating staff and the spa. I recommend Joy as massage therapist. They also have a free wine tasting from 5p-6p (woot woot) and a free coffee, tea and hot chocolate bar in the morning. The restaurant SALTROCK is top notch as well. We will be back frequently.I would definitely come back. Sony DVD player was broken in my room but that was the only minor glitch I experienced during my stay. This property is located in uptown Sedona which has plenty of shopping, and dining options well within walking distance.Nice view of the sunrise from the swimming pool, patio, and restaurant.I just had the 2 worst nights sleep of my life. Whatever you do, don't let them put you in room 101. It's next to some machine room. I can sleep through anything, except whatever is humming and whirling and rotating in this room. Totally ripped off unfortunately and not worth the money. Not a 4 star experience by any account.
review_content_60: We did Sedona right by staying at the Amara. 5 star service despite the 4 star ranking.Booking:I joined the Karma Rewards program and booked at the 20% off new customer rate through the website.  Great rewards program, lots of awesome perks as they really go the extra mile by being a boutique hotel.  Free WiFi as a rewards member too.PS - This hotel loves dogs and I love that they do (I would have brought mine if we weren't staying up at the Grand Canyon for a night).Arrival: The friendly bellman parked our car and offered to carry our bags.  We arrived right at wine hour (complimentary wine from 5-6pm).  So, we dropped off our bags and put on our swim suits, grabbed a glass of red wine, and plunged into the hot tub.   Upon our return to the room I noticed a bottle of champagne and chocolate strawberry's (my boyfriend and I were celebrating a late valentines day).  This was SO lovely and thoughtful!!! We went down to the restaurant bar for a margarita - I am extremely picky about my margaritas (do not put orange juice in my lime margarita, and REAL lime juice, please).  The bartender made a perfect margarita.Room Service:We ordered room service that night two minutes after the cut off time (an early 10pm or so?), but thankfully they excepted our order.Day 1: The bellmen told us about some hiking trails - we hiked Bear Mountain which took us 4 hours and it was terrific! We had a late dinner in the upper Sedona village at a Mexican restaurant - I think it may have been open 24/7 which was cool.Day 2:Check out was quick and easy.  We walked over to the neighboring hotel and had the most delicious brunch right on the river.Thanks for the amazing stay, Amara! The small service touches truly went a long way for us.My husband and I stayed here for our 5-year anniversary with our two dogs. We loved it! Pros: -Free Yoga in the spa every day at 8:30 am. Make sure to get there early, because the yoga room is very small. It only fits about 6 people comfortably, but can squeeze 10 side by side. -Free Breakfast Beverage Bar from 5-10 am, which includes coffees and teas. -Free Wine every night from 5-6 pm. -Free shuttle to local Sedona attractions.-Free Chapstick, deodorant, tweezers, and other beauty essentials, in case you forgot. Notice a trend here? I love free stuff!!! Cons: -You have to pay for Wifi. Wah wah. -This is a dog friendly hotel, but there is no designated dog relief area. We found a gravel area in the back, but it wasn't well lit. Overall, a great experience! It's in walking distance from Uptown Sedona, so you have access to lots of shopping. My husband signed us up for a loyalty program, and we got a free $10 credit towards the mini-bar. And on top of all that, they gave us complimentary champagne and chocolate covered strawberries to celebrate the occasion.From the moment we stepped on property, the valet and front desk staff were great. Our room was very nice and our creek side view was stunning. The patio and pool have an amazing red rock view that really can't be beat.We had dinner on the patio and the food was great! The hostess was a little eccentric and wanted to chat with patrons more than she wanted to seat guests. The live guitar music was a great touch. Our waiter was very nice but seemed a little stretched thin as they appeared to only have two servers working the entire restaurant. So we waited a while for our check, luckily we were sans kids and not in a hurry.Overall, a great stay and we'd stay again!This is not a 4 star hotel...My boyfriend and I celebrated our seven year anniversary here and we could not have had a better experience. We both work and are in school and so we didn't get in until around 9 pm. Since the restaurant was closed, the bartender helped us order pizza and gave us a round of free drinks. When we went up to our room, we found out that the concierge left a lovely plate of chocolate covered strawberries and a card for us. The resort itself is beautiful and all of the amenities there are definitely worth the extra price. I went to the free yoga class the first day and we both really enjoyed the free wine hour in the afternoon. It is also really convenient to have a free valet.With exceptional staff, a fabulous location, and beautiful views, the resort is without-a-doubt my first choice hotel in Sedona. We will definitely be back!Maybe I'm a bit spoiled, but the Amara was a bit "meh." The valets were super friendly and helpful, but the front desk staff needs help. They are friendly in a robotic way, but not in a thoughtful way. For instance when I asked about yoga class times, I was not told there was a sign up sheet. I found the signup sheet by happenstance and by that time the class I wanted was full. There are no "grounds" per say, it's a very pool-centric hotel-everything faces the pool and the pool has a weird vibe. There are the hotel pool crashers who arrived by canoe each day with their baby in tow--he had on those swimmy diapers that I find a bit revolting (they don't work, hello poop-in-the-pool. Google it-gross!) And the pool attendant refused to clear off the deck chairs and used glasses when people left so it was unclear which lounge chairs were taken and which were not. I watched people show up to the pool and look around at all of the wet towels on the chairs and lounges and leave although some of those chairs had been vacant for hours. When we asked for more towels, the attendant told us "housekeeping takes care of that." After about 45 min of no new towels, someone else loudly asked for towels and housekeeping was finally summoned. We've been to Kimpton hotels before, but this one was decidely lower end, the rooms are small, the decor so-so. The welcome wine hour was okay. Wines were predictably not good, so it was a good thing we brought our own. During the yoga class I did take, the yoga teacher began by telling us how off-put she was that she had to give up her spot since two people had signed up for one slot and the class was too full. She lectured us on honesty and taking others into consideration. Then she told us to get in touch with "joy" and proceeded to lead a non-yoga joy, healing, vibrational Sedona-New-Agey meditation class and in the midst announced that she loved all of us. WTF?Don't get a bottom floor room because although the floor is carpeted, but thin and you can hear the people above you walking around at all hours. Pricey for what you get. The restaurant Hundred Rox got so-so reviews so we steered clear. We had dinner at the lovely L'Auberge next door (delicious!) so if you want a resort get-away, I'd suggest staying there, the grounds at L'Auberge were fabulous and service was high-end and outstanding. And the food was truly amazing. THAT is a resort, the Amara, not so much.We spent 4 nights and chose this resort because of its close proximity to shops/restaurants in Uptown.  The resort is beautiful and our room located on the Creekside had a wonderful view with a balcony and was very quiet.  It was spacious as well  with a nice modern decor.  The staff was great, and the wine hour every night from 5-6pm was a nice touch! It gave us a chance to spend some time on the patio, watch the sunset and unwind before dinner.  We also had dinner on the patio one evening and it was wonderful!  Great stay!We absolutely loved the Amara.I booked after reading the reviews for my boyfriend's birthday and we came into town around check in time. It was January, and a bit cold, but they had the heaters going and it was really lovely.It is a quick turn in to the driveway/road and we did miss it the first time around, so circled back.Once we pulled in, we chose to valet as it just seemed easier. The check in was flawless. They had upgraded us to a pool (courtyard) facing room and wished my boyfriend a happy birthday as we checked in. (I had put down in the reservation that the occasion was for his b-day). When we got to our room, there was a set up of 2 plates and a card that again wished him happy birthday and said to check in the mini-fridge which had a plate of petit fours for us. It was such a nice touch. The room was decent sized with a king sized bed, a walk in closet, a stocked fridge and toiletry area (everything is for sale, nothing is free....), and a clean modern feel. Our room had a sliding door to a little patio area which would be cute to enjoy with wine if we had been staying there longer.The bathroom was small, with a good deep tub. The walk in closet was such a great touch since we had our winter wear with us. We took the complimentary shuttle up to the end of the shopping area and walked back to the hotel. The gal at the front desk had told us to look for the stairs behind the stores to get us back down to the hotel without having to take the curving driveway down. As we walked down, we passed a pretty landing with a lookout point, further down an area where they no doubt host weddings, and finally passed the spa which we did have some access to, but never used.We ventured to the lobby for our wine happy hour, and my boyfriend ordered a hot toddy which is also a choice while I had a glass of the merlot. It was either that or chardonnay. We lounged in the small area they have set up where you can play with a giant jenga set or connect4. We played a game of connect4 then decided to venture out by the pool. The one unfortunate thing was there are a few gas fire pits, but because it was cold, people seemed to "hog" them and had been there for hours. It was so cold outside, that we weren't really able to sit out there. We had asked for a heater for the table we were at, but they were all out of propane in the two that were available so we gave up and headed back to our room for a nap instead.We had reservations at the restaurant there for that evening. I had wanted to try Ken's Creekside, but the convenience of the hotel made it a simple decision.I will write a separate review for the restaurant. Over dinner, we decided we wanted to beat the crowds and get out on a 4 wheel drive adventure at sunrise, so we verified that our truck would be ready at 6:30 AM and then headed off to bed. (Oh the times of bars and all nighters have changed...)At 6:30 AM my boyfriend headed over to the lobby while I finished layering my clothes for the cold and when I got up there, the truck was ready and warm, and there was a nice coffee spread out in the lobby with a few different choices including hot tea and hot chocolate. The staff was up and chipper for so early in the morning.When we returned from the off-roading trip, we were no longer boyfriend and girlfriend, but engaged, which was a happy surprise to me. My soon-to-be husband decided to pop the question out on a gorgeous plateau during sunrise in Sedona, and we ate at Ken's Creekside for breakfast to celebrate.The pool area at Amara, while small, is truly gorgeous too, with a walk in infinity pool that looks like a sand beach, and chaise lounges everywhere. I had seen the setup for a wedding on the artificial grass behind it and thought what a magnificent place to be married. Quaint, quiet, beautiful and the nicest staff.I hope we get to go again, next time as husband and wife!I would highly recommend the Amara. It may not be a Four Seasons, but for the price, it really is lovely.This is just and AMAZING Resort! Wife and I were here to celebrate her Birthday and they had balloons and strawberries and nice card waiting inside the amazing room with balcony looking at oak creek. Just a wonderful Resort!Amazing hotel in a perfect location. The rooms are big with nice patios. Service is awesome. Beautiful pool with couches and beds surrounding the pool area. Fireplaces outside with a beautiful patio for lunch or dinner. I would recommend this hotel to anyone staying in Sedona.Amara was such an amazing hotel, especially for the price. My boyfriend and I stayed there over 4th of July weekend. The valet guys were spectacular. They were more knowledgeable about hikes and things to do than the front desk women. Although the pool was small, the view of Snoopy Rock and Oak Creek is spectacular. The hotel restaurant is great too! Get a room on the 2nd floor and be sure to order the shrimp scampi or shrimp mango nachos. Also, the bar makes the best bloody marry I've ever had!!You can read all about Sedona and the best places to go somewhere else, but for those who want to stay in a clean, wonderful hotel, with a good view, AND you can take your dog - this is the place.Spending the week in Arizona for my birthday and the Amara was our first stop. The grounds are well kept and beautifully decorated with a mix of modern furniture and art and relaxing spots to hang out. The rooms were clean, and offered a ton of snacks and toiletries in case you forgot anything. The staff was very accommodating and friendly. I went for a massage today and had Derek who was awesome. I am a hairstylist so to say I have tight muscles is an understatement. I frequently get massages and have been serviced by a male massage therapist multiple times but I have to say, Derek was beyond professional and I was able to truly relax and not feel awkward during the massage. In the past i've always felt just slightly tense, nervous that a sheet or towel would expose certain parts during the service. With Derek, the sheets were always tucked so I felt confident that they wouldn't move. At one point during the abdominal massage (which was a first for me and it was amazing! You never realized you're tense in your tummy till someone rubs it haha) he even doubled up the towel and sheet so I would be comfortable.
